@mitsudome-r Thank you for review!!

@hakuturu583 @mitsudome-r @amc-nu when building using `colcon` instead of `catkin` a _setup.bash_ and a _local_setup.bash_ files are created.
Using _local_setup.bash_ is the suggested method in [https://colcon.readthedocs.io/en/released/user/quick-start.html](https://colcon.readthedocs.io/en/released/user/quick-start.html).
_setup.bash_ will also source the parent workspace, /opt/ros/DISTRO, while this would not lead to compatibility problems at the moment, I believe it might lead to issues down the line when .Auto is also part of .Ai since /opt/ros2/DISTRO will also be sourced.
Sourcing _local_setup.bash_ seems to me like a safer way to go
@YamatoAndo Please move this PR to a fork.

@yukkysaito can you explain why do you need to add these ?
Most of these are already included in the TF library, boost, and OpenCV.

> @yukkysaito I cannot see any tests for the new functions, can you add them?

Sure, I know. I put it in the todo list, so I planned to check it when I finish. Would it have been better to issue a PR after the test?

> > @yukkysaito I cannot see any tests for the new functions, can you add them?
> 
> I put it in the todo list, so I planned to check it when I finish. Would it have been better to issue a PR after the test?

The tests are needed to consider accepting the PR, I'm afraid it will not be merged otherwise. Can you also address the query from @amc-nu?

> @yukkysaito can you explain why do you need to add these ?
> Most of these are already included in the TF library, boost, and OpenCV.

Some of them are implemented in OpenCV and others, but I think we should proceed with libraries to reduce dependencies using wrappers etc. Functions such as OpenCV are low-level APIs, and there are various common codes to use these things. We need to abstract a little more for Autoware.

And many of them are not implemented in these libraries, and cooperation between libraries reduces the readability of the code.

In Apollo, these libraries are very carefully made and commonly used. Even if I make such a library from now on, nobody uses it, so I think that it should be prepared as soon as possible.
In the future I will also implement table-based sin, cos etc.

@yukkysaito I would agree with you if we were to add them as new dependencies. That would be indeed a huge load for just a few classes. However, we use ROS, which already includes these libraries. Moreover, these are widely tested, constantly maintained, and very likely free of bugs. If you care about readability, why not build wrappers around them instead of writing from scratch?

@amc-nu 
- Basically it is implemented as a wrapper. However, because the basic algorithm necessary for autonomous driving is insufficient by itself, partly I scratched.
- Many nodes of Autoware call algorithms implemented in OpecCV, PCL, etc., and many of the code is a complicated procedure for using the library. In order to improve readability, we need to abstract a little more for Autoware.
- The current Autoware software has individual nodes relying too much on various libraries. For example, suppose you only wanted to use linear interpolation but rely on OpenCV. We will be in trouble if OpenCV becomes unusable due to version upgrade, porting problem, license problem or etc.. If it is made into a library, it can be solved by re-implementing the linear interpolation unit.
- In terms of portability, readability, and testing, algorithms and programs as ROS should be separated to some extent.

@yukkysaito I totally agree with you and this absolutely improves portability and readability.  

I would like to know the reason why you get each point (x, y, z) using `getX()`, `getY()`, and `getZ` in each function in Vector3d and Vector2d files.  
I believe you can use Eigen arithmetic operations like `Vector3d(_a. vec_ + _b.vec_)`.  
Using Eigen features would improve the inference speed.

I agree with @amc-nu . I don't see the point of this pull request, there's plenty of well-maintained and high quality math libraries, reimplementing all these algorithms in Autoware makes no sense and it's yet another part of the code that we'll have to maintain ourselves.

For a portable math library, have a look at ignition-math, developed and maintained by the Gazebo team at OSRF:

https://ignitionrobotics.org/libs/math

@esteve I know there is such libraries, so it is not reimplemented. Basically it is implemented as a wrapper. However, because the basic algorithm necessary for autonomous driving is insufficient by itself, partly I scratched. 
example, a lot of epsilon is defined to make a floating point comparison, or a bug occurs because an appropriate comparison is not done. What I implemented is such a basic function, but it is not provided by the library (numerical comparision).

The part to be maintained is a wrapper necessary for using with Autoware. If it does not exist, inconvenience of various dependency relations and writing style occurs, a bug is born and maintenance becomes difficult. 
For example, there are various vector libraries that provide the same functionality, such as openCV, Eigen and ignition, and because everyone uses different libraries, the dependency is getting worse. (https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/pull/2045#issuecomment-468334519)
Of course, if my implementation is duplicated, switch to wrapper.


What do you think about what I said here?
https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/pull/2045#issuecomment-468661079

(ignition don't provide float comparision, integral function, kf, hungarian algo, table based sin cos, polygon, etc. In order to use these functions, individual nodes will make dependencies on various libraries, which makes maintenance difficult.
https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/pull/2045#issue-256945935)
@yukitsuji Thank you! I'll change it

> @esteve I know there is such libraries, so it is not reimplemented. Basically it is implemented as a wrapper.

That's not true, for example a quick search reveals that the `numerical_comparisons.hpp` file you added in this pull request, is copied directly from:

https://github.com/ethz-asl/schweizer_messer/blob/master/sm_common/include/sm/numerical_comparisons.hpp

Do you realize that you can't just copy some random code and everything will be fine? That code has its own license (3-clause BSD), and if we added it to the Autoware codebase and not acknowledged the original authors, the Autoware Foundation would be in legal trouble for copyright infringement.

> However, because the basic algorithm necessary for autonomous driving is insufficient by itself, partly I scratched.
example, a lot of epsilon is defined to make a floating point comparison, or a bug occurs because an appropriate comparison is not done. What I implemented is such a basic function, but it is not provided by the library (numerical comparision).

You didn't implement that, you just copied it from another project.

> The part to be maintained is a wrapper necessary for using with Autoware. If it does not exist, inconvenience of various dependency relations and writing style occurs, a bug is born and maintenance becomes difficult.

No, maintenance becomes difficult when we add more lines of code arbitrarily.

> For example, there are various vector libraries that provide the same functionality, such as openCV, Eigen and ignition, and because everyone uses different libraries, the dependency is getting worse. (#2045 (comment))

Depending on other libraries not only saves us time in the short term, but also ensures that we don't have to maintain that code ourselves, so we can focus on important stuff.

> We will be in trouble if OpenCV becomes unusable due to version upgrade, porting problem, license problem or etc..

What's more likely, that you'll forget about this code in two months time or that OpenCV changes its license?

I did not copy it but I read this question and implemented it myself.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17333/what-is-the-most-effective-way-for-float-and-double-comparison
https://marycore.jp/prog/c-lang/compare-floating-point-number/
It is natural that these basic codes almost resemble each other
If there are too many objections, I will close it. What about libraries not provided?

@yukkysaito ok, let's assume you implemented it. It took me ten seconds to find an existing library, maintained by large team of developers, that implemented all that. It's a problem when the first instinct is to add new code instead of relying on existing tools. For example, do you think we need our own implementation of a Vector3? It's one of the most widely used structures in robotics.

Vector3d is a Eigen wrapper. Certainly, if something is set as the default, wrapper will not be needed.
Ok. Kalman filter and table based sin cos are necessary to develop ros node. What should these be done?

From the viewpoint of the library user, I think that it is useful an abstraction layer of math processing for the following reasons.

* Currently, some packages have their own implementation of math processing. Extract them and make it available from other packages.
* Need functions that are not included in the existing library and frequently used utility function that combines low-level functions.
* It's annoying to convert to library type such as from geometry_msgs, vector_map_msgs, or PCL to Eigen, OpenCV, or Boost. Type conversions should be isolated by wrapper since they are unrelated to the algorithm.

I feel that an using alias is better than wrapper class for vector type. My opinion is as follows.
If you use Eigen for internal implementation, define abstract vector types as Eigen type aliases and functions as Eigen function wrapper. And add your own implementation or other library functions for abstract vector types. Finally, support wrappers for other library types.
@yukkysaito what do you mean by Kalman Filter? that would depend on the sensors and purpose of the algorithm itself. Also why do you need a table of sin and cos?

> @yukkysaito what do you mean by Kalman Filter? that would depend on the sensors and purpose of the algorithm itself. Also why do you need a table of sin and cos?

Thank you.
About Kalman Filter: you are correct. However, the formulas of the Kalman filter are reusable because they can be made generalized kalman filter library. For example, we are currently developing ekf for localization estimation. Here, we have implemented a Kalman filter library that can be used generically. We want to use this library with mot (multi object tracking).
https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/blob/feature/kalman_filter/ros/src/computing/perception/localization/packages/kalman_filter_localizer/include/kalman_filter/kalman_filter.h
Table of sin and cos: Calculation of sin function is expensive because calculation is Taylor expansion. The sin function is very often used in MPC, Particle Filer, Local path palanner, etc. In addition, they generally need to run at high frequency, which makes the computational cost a bottleneck. There is still reasons, in the past experience, this is absolutely necessary.

> From the viewpoint of the library user, I think that it is useful an abstraction layer of math processing for the following reasons.
> 
> * Currently, some packages have their own implementation of math processing. Extract them and make it available from other packages.
> * Need functions that are not included in the existing library and frequently used utility function that combines low-level functions.
> * It's annoying to convert to library type such as from geometry_msgs, vector_map_msgs, or PCL to Eigen, OpenCV, or Boost. Type conversions should be isolated by wrapper since they are unrelated to the algorithm.
> 
> I feel that an using alias is better than wrapper class for vector type. My opinion is as follows.
> If you use Eigen for internal implementation, define abstract vector types as Eigen type aliases and functions as Eigen function wrapper. And add your own implementation or other library functions for abstract vector types. Finally, support wrappers for other library types.

I agree with @isamu-takagi  what vector3d is implemented as alias. Thank you for your idea

> > @yukkysaito what do you mean by Kalman Filter? that would depend on the sensors and purpose of the algorithm itself. Also why do you need a table of sin and cos?
> 
> Thank you.
> About Kalman Filter: you are correct. However, the formulas of the Kalman filter are reusable because they can be made generalized kalman filter library. For example, we are currently developing ekf for localization estimation. Here, we have implemented a Kalman filter library that can be used generically. We want to use this library with mot (multi object tracking).
> https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/blob/feature/kalman_filter/ros/src/computing/perception/localization/packages/kalman_filter_localizer/include/kalman_filter/kalman_filter.h

@yukkysaito OK, I understand what you mean by KF now. Nevertheless, if you are planning on re-using the KF for other non-localization modules, as mot. I don't think the current placement of the KF library is clear enough for new Autoware users to use.

> OK, I understand what you mean by KF now. Nevertheless, if you are planning on re-using the KF for other non-localization modules, as mot. I don't think the current placement of the KF library is clear enough for new Autoware users to use.

KF is used by many modules. MOT just wants to use it right now, and in the future, there are many modules that use KF, such as white line estimateion, IMU bias estimation, path prediction and so on. Is this not enough?

> > OK, I understand what you mean by KF now. Nevertheless, if you are planning on re-using the KF for other non-localization modules, as mot. I don't think the current placement of the KF library is clear enough for new Autoware users to use.
> 
> KF is used by many modules. MOT just wants to use it right now, and in the future, there are many modules that use KF, such as white line estimateion, IMU bias estimation, path prediction and so on. Is this not enough?

@yukkysaito I was referring to the actual location of the library within the Autoware repo. I think it would be better to have it placed in _common_ instead of inside the localization package

Again, why write from scratch when there are great libraries available.
MPRT with ROS wrappers: https://www.mrpt.org/mrpt-ros-pkg
KFilter: http://kalman.sourceforge.net/
Orocos: http://www.orocos.org/bfl/packages
OpenCV KalmanFilter Class

Or less known libraries:
http://bayesclasses.sourceforge.net/Bayesian%20Filtering%20Classes.html
@yukkysaito Please move this PR to a fork.

issues_comment_text:
@gbiggs This PR would benefit a lot from splitting the Autoware repository into smaller ones. Here's a suggestion:

- autoware_core: drivers, algorithms, low-level controllers, etc.
- autoware_utils: anything that's external to autoware_core, but does not use a UI
- autoware_visualization: anything UI-related (runtime manager, rviz plugins, etc.)

autoware_core could certainly be split into even more repositories, but these are the three main ones I could think of.

Thanks @esteve 
Even after running `rosdep update`.
I'm still getting `unable to locate package ros-melodic-jsk-recognition-utils`.

Is this related? acccording to Jenkins, it is still failing on melodic.
http://wiki.ros.org/jsk_recognition
@amc-nu are you using the `--ignore-src` option?
@esteve as @amc-nu says neither `jsk-recognition-utils` or `msgs` are currently available to install for ROS melodic. We need to revert the last commit on this branch

@esteve I'd like to figure out a timeline for getting this merged and when we can do it. If possible I'd like to have it in immediately after 1.11 so we have plenty of time to test things on Melodic before the 1.12 release. The most important things to know are:

- What are the blockers to enabling building on Melodic, and can we circumvent them? Obviously the JSK packages are major blockers but are there any others?
- Will adding support for Melodic impact building/running on Kinetic in any way?
- You stated that it would benefit from splitting the repositories. Does this PR need that done first or can we merge this before splitting? The [roadmap discussion](https://discourse.ros.org/t/autoware-ai-current-autoware-roadmap/7976) currently aims for repository splitting in 1.12, which would mean pushing merging this further into the 1.12 iteration if we need to split first.

@amc-nu @sgermanserrano `jsk-recognition-utils` and `jsk-recognition-msgs` are available in the ROS shadow repository (see http://repositories.ros.org/status_page/ros_melodic_default.html), and will be available in the next sync (1-2 weeks). Meanwhile, I can put them back in the source tree and we'll remove them during the next release cycle.

> What are the blockers to enabling building on Melodic, and can we circumvent them? Obviously the JSK packages are major blockers but are there any others?

All the missing packages in Melodic are in https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/tree/feature/melodic/ros/src/vendor. The other thing missing is a PIC-built binary for `libymc_can`, @amc-nu knows more about that.

> Will adding support for Melodic impact building/running on Kinetic in any way?

No. However, we might want to remove or comment out the `jsk_*` packages from Dockerfile so that they don't clash with the ones in `ros/src/vendor`

> You stated that it would benefit from splitting the repositories. Does this PR need that done first or can we merge this before splitting? The roadmap discussion currently aims for repository splitting in 1.12, which would mean pushing merging this further into the 1.12 iteration if we need to split first.

I don't think splitting the repositories precludes adding support for Melodic. However, it may have the benefit of users being able to have the core of Autoware (planning, perception, drivers, etc.) running on Melodic (on a vehicle, for example), while having tools and the visualization plugins still running on Kinetic (on a desktop). Separating the core from the external tools would also make the introduction of Autoware.Auto as a dependency easier, since we can add support for Melodic incrementally (in case there's a problem with the tools or the rviz plugins).

@esteve @gbiggs autowarefoundation/autoware#1946 installs the dependencies using `rosdep` in the Dockerfile so there should be no collision if the `jsk_*` packages are included in the _vendor_ folder. The removal will be needed in the _crossbuild/Dockerfile_ for now

@sgermanserrano the problem with rosdep is that it doesn't benefit from the Docker cache properly. Also, ROS1 doesn't guarantee any ABI compatiblity across releases, so if I happen to have the rosdep call cached and then I install a ROS package that was released at a later sync, I'll most certainly get a crash.
@esteve the `rosdep` has been added to the Dockerfiles to reduce maintainability needs as new packages have new dependencies, when building the base image it is more straightforward

@sgermanserrano I don't think it's a good idea, for the reasons I mentioned. A more correct approach would be to run rosdep as an automated process (e.g. Travis), check if there are new dependencies and then add them to Dockerfile so as to have a complete trace of all the ROS packages that are needed.
I agree with @esteve. We need the Dockerfiles to allow as deterministic a run as possible every time.

With the latest Melodic sync, it should be possible to build Autoware without bundling the dependencies in this PR. I'll remove them and spin a CI to make sure it all works https://discourse.ros.org/t/new-packages-for-melodic-2019-03-04/8120
Yay for recursion!

@esteve I'm getting confused with the last _Revert Revert..._. `jsk_recognition_utils` and `jsk_rviz_plugins` are available to be installed as part of ROS Melodic, but I can see the _vendor_ folder is still there
@sgermanserrano the `jsk_rviz_plugins` is still bundled, but I saw that it's available in Melodic as well. Good catch, I'll remove the entire vendor directory. Thanks!
@esteve Are we going to get this in for 1.11? Or alternatively can it be merged as-is without breaking master? I looked over the changes and didn't see anything bad, but it's a large PR.
@gbiggs there are some bugs (#2097 autowarefoundation/autoware#2098 autowarefoundation/autoware_ai#603 autowarefoundation/autoware#2101) that need addressing before we can have melodic support
@esteve @sgermanserrano can you please consider autowarefoundation/autoware#2145 ?

> There is one caveat: In order to build the CUDA/DNN stuff, CMake >= 3.12 and Eigen >=3.3.5 are required (in addition to CUDA 10.0). I created a script to install them (hopefully non-destructively):

Just to clarify, does this mean that the versions in Ubuntu 18.04 are too old?

@gbiggs yes
Please check autowarefoundation/autoware_ai#593 and autowarefoundation/autoware_ai#602

@JWhitleyAStuff Asking users to install non-system versions of critical packages like CMake is risky. Many users may end up causing more problems for themselves. Of course, we shouldn't just say "No GPU for you" and leave it at that, but we do need to be careful. Here's how we propose to allow the user to enable GPU support but also ensure that they are forced to know at least a little of what they are doing first.

1. Add an option to the relevant packages to enable GPU. Make it off by default. Document that to use GPU you must enable that option in ccmake.
2. If disabled, use CPU and be happy with Ubuntu versions
3. If enabled, look for necessary eigen and CMake versions and break if not found.
4. If those tools are recent enough and CUDA is not found, break.
5. Otherwise, build

Does this sound reasonable to you?
@gbiggs SGTM. I know @esteve is pretty burried at the moment. Should I implement on a fork of this branch and create a new PR?

It's times like this when I wish we would use conan (https://conan.io/) to handle dependencies. Alternatively, we could do like ROS2 does with external dependencies and create an eigen_vendor package (see https://github.com/ros2/yaml_cpp_vendor for an example).

As for CMake, @JWhitleyAStuff is it because the CUDA stuff uses the built-in language support? (https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.12/module/FindCUDA.html)
@esteve - I'll look into it more. I'm not positive yet.

@esteve I'm currently looking into it. It appears to be something that was added between 3.12.1 and 3.12.2. Back-porting the change to 3.10 (the version available on Ubuntu 18.04) fixes the issue so I'm seeing if it is something we can fake here. One option would be providing our own FindCUDA.cmake in the appropriate packages (a 3.10 + fix version). I'm checking to see if there is a simpler solution that we can just apply to our own CMakeLists.txt files.

issues_title: [DON'T MERGE YET] [Fix] Catching up upstream CPFL/Velodyne
issues_comment_text:
@kfunaoka @amc-nu @aohsato the differences between the updated CPFL/velodyne fork that is being used in Autoware and the upstream version of the drivers is limited to a bunch of launch and yaml files and an _if_ statement in _driver.cc_. See images
It is the right time to remove the code from the Autoware repo and use the upstream version directly. The change to _driver.cc_ should be pushed upstream and the launch and yaml files can be kept in the Autoware repo if they are Autoware-dependent.

issues_comment_text:
Hello @sgvandijk , I agree it is very big PR , specially when all files that uses op_utility are changed. 
I have a suggestion, 
1- keep (revert) the old op_utility library. 
2- add the updated one as new library (file name, class, functions, variables)  + testing -> PR 1 
3- change op_library start using the new utility library replacing the old in packages one by one 
3.1 - op_planner -> PR 2 
3.2 - op_ros_helpers & op_simu -> PR 3 
3.3 - op_global _planner -> PR 4 
and so on .. 
what do you think ? 
once PR 1 is approved I will start working on the rest. 
and this could be the strategy for the other libraries

@amc-nu See below reply to the different points:

> @filiperinaldi @sgermanserrano Thanks for all the effort put on this PR. Looks great.
> 
> I have some questions/observations:
> 
>     1. Is there any recommended nvidia-docker version?
There is a need to use nvidia-docker v2

>     2. I would suggest adding `--rm` to the `docker build` in the scripts.
> 
Added in [https://github.com/filiperinaldi/Autoware/pull/13](https://github.com/filiperinaldi/Autoware/pull/13)
>     3. After pulling the branch and running `./run.sh` I get a message telling me the image ` autoware/autoware:latest-kinetic-cuda` is not available. Do you plan to upload it to docker hub before or after merging this PR?
> 
I have pushed the missing images to Dockerhub. I have built the base images using a checkout of tag 1.10.0 and pulled and re-tagged the already available _1.10.0-kinetic_ with the new naming structures so that the previous ones are not overwritten
>     4. I'm getting an error when building the CUDA version. `liblibdpm_ttic.so: undefined reference to 'cuMemFree_v2'` (Plus other undefined references when linking that same file). I think this PR might be missing autowarefoundation/autoware#2000 . Can you confirm? If that's the case, it will be fixed after merging, so please ignore this point.
> 
I can confirm that autowarefoundation/autoware#2000 solves it. @filiperinaldi will rebase the current _develop_ to get the latest update
>     5. CPU version builds flawlessly. However, seems it still doesn't contain autowarefoundation/autoware#1861 autowarefoundation/autoware#1990 it is also pointing to `devel` space. I wasn't able to run anything inside the container.
> 
> 
This is resolved as per [https://github.com/filiperinaldi/Autoware/pull/13](https://github.com/filiperinaldi/Autoware/pull/13)

@esteve the OpenGL support for the CUDA-enabled images is inherited from autowarefoundation/autoware#1416 which in turn was inherited from autowarefoundation/autoware#1167. This contains the $LIB that you mention, by the look of this [this issue](https://github.com/a2o/snoopy/issues/112) it seems that $LIB is meant to be used to support having 32 and 64bit versions of a particular library. I think we are safe to remove those lines (done in [https://github.com/filiperinaldi/Autoware/pull/13](https://github.com/filiperinaldi/Autoware/pull/13)).

I think autowarefoundation/autoware#1901 is mandatory so that the CHANGELOGs are generated correctly at next release v1.10.1 or v1.11.0. If autowarefoundation/autoware#1901 is not merged, catkin_generate_changelog can not distinguish between which commits are v1.10.0 and which commits are next release.

From @alexandrx 
> Regarding @amc-nu comment before, you can easily check:
```for I in `find <AUTOWARE-PATH> -type f -name "package.xml"`; do grep -i "<license" -H $I; done | grep BSD | wc -l```
there are 127 different packages stating `<license>BSD</license>`.
Change the last part `grep BSD` by `grep -i apache` and there are only 5 packages stating Apache, and from those 5 only one package says "Apache 2". There are also some "TODO" licenses, 1 "gpl" and 1 "nonstandard".
As you know, you can fix all the package.xml files with the following trivial script:
```for I in `find <AUTOWARE-PATH> -type f -name "package.xml"`; do sed -i 's/<license>BSD/<license>Apache 2.0/g' $I; done```
(just in case)

Before doing that, we need to distinguish which packages can be Apache2 :)

My suggestion at the issue is that drivers can not be changed to Apache2 in my understanding.

Are there any other comments?

issues_title: Revert "Use colcon as the build tool"
issues_comment_text: Thanks @amc-nu again for finding and fixing the bugs that were introduced in #1704

I was able to compile with colcon, catkin, catkin_isolated and industrial_ci.
Thanks for your feedback @esteve @sgermanserrano 

I think we can close autowarefoundation/autoware#1838 , unless your best opinion
@amc-nu I'll close autowarefoundation/autoware#1838 , thanks for fixing the bugs! We'll have colcon in Autoware 1.10 :-)
CI https://gitlab.com/esteve/Autoware/pipelines/42438134
@esteve Can we close this and do each package as we reorganise the repository/packages?

@sgermanserrano @amc-nu Should this pull request be imported into GitLab CI?
https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/blob/develop/.gitlab-ci.yml
No, this won’t affect and doesn’t intend to modify Gitlab way more complex setup
@amc-nu It might also improve/simplify the Gitlab setup, I'll check what would need to be changed.

@amc-nu this is great, thanks for pushing it. It'd be great reconcile the different CI systems into one, I believe the best scenario would be to have one single "source of truth" that includes all the features of each CI.

We currently have:

- the industrial_ci integration done by @amc-nu 
- @sgermanserrano 's work on GitLab
- the deprecated Travis scripts
- the AutowareAuto CI infrastructure (cc @dejanpan )
- the switch to colcon so we can introduce ROS2 into Autoware.ai

I'd say that adding multiple CI systems would incur in a significant amount of work maintaining so much infrastructure, we should narrow it down to only one that satisfies our requirements.

My takeaways:

- industrial_ci is very mature, but does not support ROS2 yet. We could work on getting colcon used upstream, so that we can support both ROS1 and ROS2.
- The AutowareAuto CI infrastructure uses colcon, this would require https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/pull/1704 to be merged. AutowareAuto also has support for Marv, an online repository for rosbags
- @sgermanserrano first ported the functionality of the legacy Travis scripts to GitLab. And then he extended it (e.g to support code coverage), which was always the plan.
- Some of the benefits of industrial_ci are already in colcon (like checking the install target, test report, etc.)

@esteve @sgermanserrano How about merging this pull request? Since current travis script is already obsolete, this pull request might be useful in some situation until GitLab CI supports industrial_ci even if the results of travis might be ignored by developers. Though there are some challenges @esteve listed, this pull request is harmless and valuable for a short time, I think.
I don't like to execute industrial_ci every time on my PC.

issues_title: No package mactching ros-galactic-desktop available  for AWSIM-stable branch in Ubuntu 22.04
issues_comment_text:
@anilbommareddy 
Currently, the official support for AWSIM is only ROS2 Galactic, Ubuntu20.04.

For Ubuntu 22.04, try work in progress version which includes our individual repos but will be officially supported soon:
Autoware: https://github.com/shmpwk/autoware/tree/humble-awsim-stable
AWSIM: https://github.com/tier4/AWSIM/tree/humble

Try the following command
```
git clone https://github.com/shmpwk/autoware/
cd autoware
git checkout humble-awsim-stable
./setup-dev-env.sh  #*/enter Y and install cuda-Y.
mkdir src
vcs import src < autoware.repos
source /opt/ros/humble/setup.bash
rosdep update
rosdep install -y --from-paths src --ignore-src --rosdistro $ROS_DISTRO
colcon build --symlink-install --cmake-args -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS="-w"
source install/setup.bash
ros2 launch autoware_launch e2e_simulator.launch.xml vehicle_model:=sample_vehicle sensor_model:=awsim_sensor_kit map_path:=<your mapfile location>
```

Note that when launching AWSIM, you need its binary. But currently we have only Galactic version of binary.
You have to create AWSIM binary for Humble by yourself from https://github.com/tier4/AWSIM/tree/humble.

without output.

This issue is very old. We have switched to a new base container and ROS 2 humble. This issue might not be present anymore.

Please if you test this with the latest containers and the issue persists, feel free to re-open this issue.

For `target_velocity` and `target_acceleration`, It might be better to separate these as vehicle command message.
For `geo_point`, this cannot be provided if the map only has local coordinates.

> For `target_velocity` and `target_acceleration`, It might be better to separate these as vehicle command message. For `geo_point`, this cannot be provided if the map only has local coordinates.

Sorry for late reply, I miss the message.
I agree that we should move the `target_velocity` and `target_acceleration` to vehicle_command.
We should just put in the current vehicle status data

For the `geo_point` I think we might able to convert from MGRS to the global longitude and latitude

I created the document for vehicle status
https://autowarefoundation.github.io/autoware-documentation/pr-312/design/autoware-interfaces/ad-api/list/api/vehicle/

> For the geo_point I think we might able to convert from MGRS to the global longitude and latitude

According to [the lanelet2_extension documentation](https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware_common/tree/main/tmp/lanelet2_extension#io), Autoware works in a local coordinate system independent of MGRS by setting `local_x` and `local_y`.

I forgot the API to control doors. I have three suggestions.

1. array command
```yaml
message:
  - NONE
  - CLOSE
  - CLOSE
  - NONE
```

2. index command
```yaml
message:
  - { index: 1, command: CLOSE }
  - { index: 2, command: CLOSE }
```

3. role command
```yaml
message:
  - { role: GET_ON, command: CLOSE }
```

cuda_base_image=ubuntu:22.04
>>>>>>> main
cuda_version=11.6
cudnn_version=8.4.1.50-1+cuda11.6
tensorrt_version=8.4.2-1+cuda11.6

issues_title: perf(docker): reduce prebuilt docker image size
issues_comment_text:
@Sharrrrk I'm sorry to be late.
We need to upgrade the CUDA version to 11.8 or 12.0 to use a CUDA image for the base image. However, since there is no arm64 (sbsa) version provided yet, we can't upgrade the version.
See also https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/pull/3084#discussion_r1035826071.

So, until then, I think using `ubuntu:22.04` for the base image is okay.

issues_title: perf(docker): reduce prebuilt docker image size
issues_comment_text:
> @Sharrrrk I'm sorry to be late. We need to upgrade the CUDA version to 11.8 or 12.0 to use a CUDA image for the base image. However, since there is no arm64 (sbsa) version provided yet, we can't upgrade the version. See also [#3084 (comment)](https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/pull/3084#discussion_r1035826071).
> 
> So, until then, I think using `ubuntu:22.04` for the base image is okay.

Do you mean we should set both base_image and cuda_base_image to ubuntu:22.04 for now?

issues_title: perf(docker): reduce prebuilt docker image size
issues_comment_text: @Sharrrrk Yes, exactly. It will be resolved in https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/pull/3084, but arm64 TensorRT packages aren't released yet. We have to wait for that.
Considering https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/pull/2912, I updated this PR.
The following labels could not be found: `github-actions`.

issues_title: [CI] `pipx install ansible` fails on the self-hosted runner.
issues_comment_text:
Seeing the logs, it seems it fails if the OS version is different?
https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/actions/workflows/build-humble-self-hosted.yaml
https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/actions/workflows/build-main-self-hosted.yaml

Related: https://github.com/pypa/pipx/issues/278

issues_title: [CI] `pipx install ansible` fails on the self-hosted runner.
issues_comment_text:
I guess it will be resolved if we move to Humble.
So, I'll stop `build-main-self-hosted` and mark this issue as not planned.

issues_title: ci(backport): use generated token instead of GITHUB_TOKEN
ci(backport): use generated token instead of GITHUB_TOKEN
issues_comment_text:
@kenji-miyake 
Without same fix as this PR, I make a PR https://github.com/h-ohta/autoware/pull/3 , and make  a backport PR https://github.com/h-ohta/autoware/pull/5. Then git hub actions does not works.

issues_title: ci(backport): use generated token instead of GITHUB_TOKEN
issues_comment_text:
Ah, I understand
If you don't use a technique like https://github.blog/changelog/2022-09-08-github-actions-use-github_token-with-workflow_dispatch-and-repository_dispatch/, `GITHUB_TOKEN` doesn't trigger other workflows recursively.
It's the same as this issue: https://github.com/tibdex/backport/issues/55

So it's reasonable to accept this change.

issues_title: ci(backport): use generated token instead of GITHUB_TOKEN
issues_comment_text: @kenji-miyake I did not know same issue. Thank you for your information and review.

issues_title: Autoware humble doesn't compile without CUDA
issues_comment_text:
Hmm it installed
```
executing command [sudo -H apt-get install -y ros-humble-cudnn-cmake-module]
executing command [sudo -H apt-get install -y ros-humble-tensorrt-cmake-module]
```

Now it seems to be working. Thanks for the help.

`pip3 install ansible` in the container (root) is probably the problem.
https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/issues/2849#issuecomment-1238964827
https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/issues/2849#issuecomment-1238966584
Summary: https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/issues/2849#issuecomment-1239001602

https://hub.docker.com/_/ubuntu

Old

```
ubuntu                                                                                20.04                                                                         53df61775e88   4 months ago    72.8MB
```

New

```
ubuntu                                                                                20.04                                                                         a0ce5a295b63   5 days ago      72.8MB
```

minimal code to reproduce this problem:

```bash
docker run --rm -it ubuntu:20.04 /bin/bash
apt update && apt -y install python3-pip
pip3 install ansible
apt -y install python3-openssl
pip
```

This is okay, so some necessary files for ansible are overwritten by python3-openssl (which is installed by ROS).

```
docker run --rm -it ubuntu:20.04 /bin/bash
apt update && apt -y install python3-pip
apt -y install python3-openssl
pip3 install ansible
pip
```

This was okay.

```
docker run --rm -it ubuntu:20.04 /bin/bash
apt update && apt -y install python3-pip
apt -y install python3-openssl
pip3 install ansible
apt -y purge python3-openssl
apt autoremove
apt -y install python3-openssl
pip
```

Considering the following result, the problem is:
- If `python3-openssl` is installed before Ansible, Ansible won't install `cryptography`.
- If `python3-openssl` isn't installed before Ansible, Ansible will install `cryptography`.
  - And if we install `python3-openssl` after that, the APT version of `cryptography` is newly installed and referenced from `pip`, which causes an error.

```console
$ docker run --rm -it ubuntu:20.04 /bin/bash
$ apt update && apt -y install python3-pip
$ apt -y install python3-openssl
$ pip3 install ansible
$ apt -y purge python3-openssl
$ apt autoremove
$ pip3 install ansible
Requirement already satisfied: ansible in /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages (6.3.0)
Requirement already satisfied: ansible-core~=2.13.3 in /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages (from ansible) (2.13.3)
Requirement already satisfied: jinja2>=3.0.0 in /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages (from ansible-core~=2.13.3->ansible) (3.1.2)
Collecting cryptography
  Downloading cryptography-38.0.0-cp36-abi3-manylinux_2_17_x86_64.manylinux2014_x86_64.whl (4.1 MB)
     |████████████████████████████████| 4.1 MB 17.7 MB/s
Requirement already satisfied: PyYAML>=5.1 in /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages (from ansible-core~=2.13.3->ansible) (6.0)
Requirement already satisfied: resolvelib<0.9.0,>=0.5.3 in /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages (from ansible-core~=2.13.3->ansible) (0.8.1)

issues_title: Reduce docker image size for runtime usages
issues_comment_text:
With docker image built from nvidia/cuda:11.4.0-runtime-ubuntu20.04, and runtime dependencies installed for autoware, the disk usage of `/usr/local/cuda-11.4` folder could be reduced by 2.2GB.

Original:   `4.0G    /usr/local/cuda-11.4`
New:        `1.8G    /usr/local/cuda-11.4`

DNN related runtime dependencies:
- `libcudnn8`
- `libnvinfer8`
- `libnvinfer-plugin8`
- `libnvonnxparsers8`
- `libnvparsers8`

issues_title: Reduce docker image size for runtime usages
issues_comment_text:
Currently I'm thinking of two approaches of this work:

- Reduce size of `prebuilt` image
  Considering the prebuilt images is for users to try out Autoware quickly, dev environment could be remove from it. 

- Keep current `prebuilt` image and build another `runtime` image
  This allows users to rebuild partial of Autoware, not the whole project using prebuilt image, then runtime image may be provided just for execution. 

The main concept of size reducing:
- Only use runtime libraries for CUDA/TensorRT (This could save ~2.2GB)
- Only copy the `install` folder or maybe also keep `src` folder (This could save up to ~3.3GB)

@kenji-miyake, what's your opinion about it ?

issues_title: Reduce docker image size for runtime usages
issues_comment_text:
@Sharrrrk Thank you for investigating this issue!
I totally agree with you, and either option seems okay. The first option would be better as a first step because it's simpler.

issues_title: Reduce docker image size for runtime usages
issues_comment_text:
@Sharrrrk thanks for taking this on!

For inspiration, you could take a look at the images layers which ROS and NVIDIA have used to create their Docker images. See
* https://github.com/osrf/docker_images/blob/3f4fbca923d80f834f3a89b5960bad5582652519/ros/galactic/ubuntu/focal/ros-core/Dockerfile
* https://hub.docker.com/layers/nvidia/cuda/11.4.2-runtime-ubuntu18.04/images/sha256-9fd4770341bd8f2cd754b70d552dfd0cc5e6e3ed1406449f00b1c5bb944133b0?context=explore

I'd recommend building up a new container and not removing from an existing one.

issues_title: Reduce docker image size for runtime usages
issues_comment_text: Hi @kasperornmeck, I looked into the docker file of Nvidia and ROS, Nvidia used a script from outside to install all the packages, and for ROS, it's just like what have been implented in current ansible script. So I would say that use nvidia runtime docker image as base would be a good and neat approach. I will modify the ansible srcipts (add a variant that only installs runtime dependencies) and the Docker file (use mutlti stage build) of course, so that the `prebuilt` image could reduce it's size in later build.

Build CI: https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/runs/8128283921?check_suite_focus=true

> Use lower_case for ConstexprVariableCase.

For message type, the rosidl disallows the use of constant names other than `UPPER_CASE`. Can this pass the check? And the google guideline says to use `kConstatntName`. So is this Autoware's own rule?

> For message type, the rosidl disallows the use of constant names other than UPPER_CASE. Can this pass the check?

I've confirmed this behavior. `clang-tidy` didn't raise warnings unless we intentionally add `-system-headers` and `-header-fileter=.*`.
Since it only affects to user code, I think it's acceptable.

> And the google guideline says to use kConstatntName. So is this Autoware's own rule?

Yes. I personally think it's acceptable considering one of the rationales `consistency across languages` in ROS 2 Docs.

As you write [here](https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe/blob/3cae6eca45b36b75c696780e67aabaee05330629/common/autoware_ad_api_specs/include/autoware_ad_api_specs/routing.hpp#L50-L53), it is natural that we use lower_case for `constexpr` variables.

@isamu-takagi What do you think?

issues_title: Autoware.Universe Docker Installation Procedures are wrong
issues_comment_text:
I followed the instructions from https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware-documentation/blob/main/docs/installation/autoware/docker-installation.md with a fresh clone. I installed the dependencies using Ansible and ran in a amd64 architecture with a NVIDIA GPU.

I had no issue until building Autoware where I had the following error caused by missing dependencies:
```
--- stderr: tier4_pcl_extensions                                                  
In file included from /home/mclement/autoware/test_docker/src/universe/autoware.universe/sensing/tier4_pcl_extensions/src/voxel_grid_nearest_centroid.cpp:52:
/home/mclement/autoware/test_docker/src/universe/autoware.universe/sensing/tier4_pcl_extensions/include/tier4_pcl_extensions/voxel_grid_nearest_centroid_impl.hpp:66:10: fatal error: range/v3/all.hpp: No such file or directory
   66 | #include <range/v3/all.hpp>
      |          ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
```
I installed the missing dependencies using the following commands.
```
sudo apt update
source /opt/ros/galactic/setup.bash
rosdep update
rosdep install --from-paths . --ignore-src --rosdistro $ROS_DISTRO
```
After that I could build without error and could run Autoware without any problem.

@Croquembouche please share more details about the issues you encountered.
It is possible that there are issues when installing dependencies without Ansible, when running without NVIDIA GPU, or when using an arm64 architecture.

For now I will open a PR to add the commands needed to install missing dependencies.

issues_title: Autoware.Universe Docker Installation Procedures are wrong
issues_comment_text:
> You are right `rocker` does not support option `--cuda` but I am also using version `0.2.10` and I did not have issue. I cannot find any use of the option `--cuda` in the commands listed in the instructions but maybe it was recently changed. I am not sure what the `invalid-cross device id` could be. I will wait for more details.

Hi,

The invalid cross device id comes when you update the nvidia drivers within the docker. Because rocker uses the gpu data from the host pc, and the autoware docker uses cuda 10.1 (latest cuda version is 11.7) and needs to be updated, the installer will try to update the driver on the host pc, resulting in invalid cross device id. 

This issue has been solved in another issue. 

I'll attach the docker image that worked for me and the steps.

issues_title: Autoware.Universe Docker Installation Procedures are wrong
issues_comment_text:
Steps to use Autoware.Universe in Docker(Rocker):

1. Use this image ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-cuda. This image includes cuda 11.6, TensorRT, and CudaDNN.
2. start rocker using this command, "rocker --nvidia --x11 --user --env NVIDIA_DRIVER_CAPABILITIES="" -- ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-cuda". This will allow the host gpu to be used in the docker.
3. You need at least 64GB free RAM to colcon build the project. Having less free memory might result in random CPP error. "colcon build" will throw error and terminate the build if the pc runs out of memory. The "Add SWAP memory" section in the documentation can be used to solve this issue.

issues_title: Autoware.Universe Docker Installation Procedures are wrong

issues_title: Autoware.Universe Docker Installation Procedures are wrong
issues_comment_text:
After some offline discussion, I was able to better understand the issue.
- Installation of the **CUDA drivers on the host machine is missing** from the Docker installation instructions and from the Ansible playbook.

Currently, if someone starts from a fresh install of Ubuntu 20.04 and simply follows the Docker installation instruction, the CUDA drivers will be missing.
This can be solved by installing all dependencies (`./setup-dev-env.sh`) but it would be better if this was included in the Docker dependencies (`./setup-dev-env.sh docker`).

> what should i do to fix this problem? I find the cudnn and tensorrt files (.h .so) in the docker container.

This error is probably caused by the following missing package: `ros-galactic-tensorrt-cmake-module`.
Missing packages can be installed with the following command:
```console
rosdep install -y --from-paths src --ignore-src --rosdistro $ROS_DISTRO
```

issues_title: revert: install each package of tensorrt
issues_comment_text:
Memo: How to test this. cc @xmfcx 

## Set up CUDA

```bash
docker run --rm -it ubuntu:22.04 # Please use 20.04 if you test Galactic

# only humble
echo "deb http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu focal main restricted" > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/focal.list

apt update && apt -y install curl wget
wget https://developer.download.nvidia.com/compute/cuda/repos/ubuntu2004/x86_64/cuda-keyring_1.0-1_all.deb
dpkg -i cuda-keyring_1.0-1_all.deb
apt update
DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive apt -y install cuda-11-6
```

## Optional steps to save the intermediate image

```console
$ docker ps
$ docker commit 1a7d8855713d # Please use your own hash
sha256:b10bc67c457927004bf200344651675aee3e2260c69ff0101ca8098495f2c13e
```

issues_title: feat(morai_msgs): appending a message package for MORAI SIM: Drive
Append morai_msgs package related to testing codes about checking simulator compatibility
issues_comment_text:
Closing since:
- https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/pull/2740
is merged.

And it is still present:
https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/blob/c9c4546705bc5a3ef4ebaff0cd151e32b1a5b16b/autoware.repos#L36-L39

@ambroise-arm Here are my test results. It seems to be working correctly. :+1: 

Up: With this PR
Down: Without this PR
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31987104/180099528-152e839c-6017-4bba-9b35-508c9027860b.png)

Without this PR, `vkcube` moves extremely fast.
https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31987104/180100117-afcd5521-8ad9-4c20-8805-8a737cd9e6b0.mp4

```dockerfile
from ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-cuda

## Register Vulkan GPU vendors
ADD "https://gitlab.com/nvidia/container-images/vulkan/raw/dc389b0445c788901fda1d85be96fd1cb9410164/nvidia_icd.json" /etc/vulkan/icd.d/nvidia_icd.json
RUN chmod 644 /etc/vulkan/icd.d/nvidia_icd.json
ADD "https://gitlab.com/nvidia/container-images/opengl/raw/ubuntu20.04/glvnd/runtime/10_nvidia.json" /etc/glvnd/egl_vendor.d/10_nvidia.json
RUN chmod 644 /etc/glvnd/egl_vendor.d/10_nvidia.json
```

With this PR:
```bash
docker build . -t autoware-pr-2736
docker run --rm -it --gpus all -e NVIDIA_DRIVER_CAPABILITIES=all -e DISPLAY -v /tmp/.X11-unix:/tmp/.X11-unix:rw -v $HOME/.Xauthority:$HOME/.Xauthority:rw -e XAUTHORITY=$HOME/.Xauthority --net=host autoware-pr-2736:latest
apt update && apt install vulkan-tools
vulkaninfo | grep NVIDIA
vkcube
```

Without this PR:
```bash
docker run --rm -it --gpus all -e NVIDIA_DRIVER_CAPABILITIES=all -e DISPLAY -v /tmp/.X11-unix:/tmp/.X11-unix:rw -v $HOME/.Xauthority:$HOME/.Xauthority:rw -e XAUTHORITY=$HOME/.Xauthority --net=host ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-cuda
apt update && apt install vulkan-tools
vulkaninfo | grep NVIDIA
vkcube
```

From original [vulkan readme](https://gitlab.com/nvidia/container-images/vulkan/-/blob/master/README.md#headless-vulkaninfo):
```bash
docker run --gpus all \
   -e NVIDIA_DISABLE_REQUIRE=1 \
   -e NVIDIA_DRIVER_CAPABILITIES=all --device /dev/dri \
   -v /etc/vulkan/icd.d/nvidia_icd.json:/etc/vulkan/icd.d/nvidia_icd.json \
   -v /etc/vulkan/implicit_layer.d/nvidia_layers.json:/etc/vulkan/implicit_layer.d/nvidia_layers.json \
   -v /usr/share/glvnd/egl_vendor.d/10_nvidia.json:/usr/share/glvnd/egl_vendor.d/10_nvidia.json \
   -it nvidia/vulkan:1.3-470 \
    bash
```

**My answered questions:**
- Should we put a copy of the `nvidia_icd.json` and the `10_nvidia.json` instead of recommended mounting recommendations?
  - This was also asked by @kenji-miyake and answered by you [in here](https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/pull/2736/files#discussion_r923171341).
  - I am ok with your reasoning/solution.
- I couldn't find where the `https://gitlab.com/nvidia/container-images/vulkan/raw/dc389b0445c788901fda1d85be96fd1cb9410164/nvidia_icd.json` file was directing to in the [vulkan repository](https://gitlab.com/nvidia/container-images/vulkan) so I was going to ask where it is from.
  - You discussed this [in above here](https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/pull/2736#discussion_r922863077)
  - I still don't like that we are downloading these files instead of mounting them from the host, because it is not the recommended way.
  - But I understand your concerns for ease of use and simplicity of the implementation. So let's make it like this as long as things work.


**Small question:**
- Why did we not include `nvidia_layers.json` file from [the same readme](https://gitlab.com/nvidia/container-images/vulkan/-/blob/master/README.md#headless-vulkaninfo)? (not that I know what it does🤷‍♂️)

@kenji-miyake @xmfcx Thanks for the review.

From [nvidia documentation](https://download.nvidia.com/XFree86/Linux-aarch64/455.45.01/README/installedcomponents.html):
> An additional Vulkan layer configuration file is installed as /etc/vulkan/implicit_layer.d/nvidia_layers.json. These layers add functionality to the Vulkan loader.

I'm not sure what that implies, but it seems to work fine without it. And I hadn't come across that file before reading the vulkan readme, which is why it isn't part of the commit. We can add it if someone finds a usecase where it is needed.

issues_title: ci(docker-build-and-push): remove a workaround for docker/bake-action
issues_comment_text: Probably it's thanks to https://github.com/actions/runner-images/releases/tag/ubuntu20%2F20220828.1.

I've tested the following commands locally and it seems working well.

```console
❯ ./docker/build.sh
+ docker buildx bake --load --progress=plain -f /home/kenji/autoware/docker/autoware-universe/docker-bake.hcl --set '*.context=/home/kenji/autoware/docker/../' --set '*.ssh=default' --set '*.platform=linux/amd64' --set '*.args.ROS_DISTRO=galactic' --set '*.args.BASE_IMAGE=ubuntu:20.04' --set '*.args.SETUP_ARGS=--no-cuda-drivers' --set devel.tags=ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-cuda --set prebuilt.tags=ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-prebuilt-cuda
```

```console
❯ ./docker/build.sh --no-cuda
+ docker buildx bake --load --progress=plain -f /home/kenji/autoware/docker/autoware-universe/docker-bake.hcl --set '*.context=/home/kenji/autoware/docker/../' --set '*.ssh=default' --set '*.platform=linux/amd64' --set '*.args.ROS_DISTRO=galactic' --set '*.args.BASE_IMAGE=ubuntu:20.04' --set '*.args.SETUP_ARGS=--no-nvidia' --set devel.tags=ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest --set prebuilt.tags=ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-prebuilt
```

```console
❯ ./docker/build.sh --platform linux/amd64
+ docker buildx bake --load --progress=plain -f /home/kenji/autoware/docker/autoware-universe/docker-bake.hcl --set '*.context=/home/kenji/autoware/docker/../' --set '*.ssh=default' --set '*.platform=linux/amd64' --set '*.args.ROS_DISTRO=galactic' --set '*.args.BASE_IMAGE=ubuntu:20.04' --set '*.args.SETUP_ARGS=--no-cuda-drivers' --set devel.tags=ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-cuda --set prebuilt.tags=ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-prebuilt-cuda
```

```console
❯ ./docker/build.sh --platform linux/arm64
+ docker buildx bake --load --progress=plain -f /home/kenji/autoware/docker/autoware-universe/docker-bake.hcl --set '*.context=/home/kenji/autoware/docker/../' --set '*.ssh=default' --set '*.platform=linux/arm64' --set '*.args.ROS_DISTRO=galactic' --set '*.args.BASE_IMAGE=ubuntu:20.04' --set '*.args.SETUP_ARGS=--no-cuda-drivers' --set devel.tags=ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-cuda --set prebuilt.tags=ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-prebuilt-cuda
```

```console
❯ ./docker/build.sh --platform linux/arm64 --no-cuda
+ docker buildx bake --load --progress=plain -f /home/kenji/autoware/docker/autoware-universe/docker-bake.hcl --set '*.context=/home/kenji/autoware/docker/../' --set '*.ssh=default' --set '*.platform=linux/arm64' --set '*.args.ROS_DISTRO=galactic' --set '*.args.BASE_IMAGE=ubuntu:20.04' --set '*.args.SETUP_ARGS=--no-nvidia' --set devel.tags=ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest --set prebuilt.tags=ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:galactic-latest-prebuilt
```

issues_title: Create separate containers for testing Open AD Kit
issues_comment_text:
The original issues created for this work are below:
- https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.ai/issues/2447
- https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware-documentation/issues/101
- https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware-projects/issues/36
- https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware-projects/issues/37

The top two issues relate to creating some kind of automated build process for Autoware as a microservices architecture, and then the bottom two issues are for the initial microservices PoC work, that assumed that we would be splitting Perception into its own container.

issues_title: Create separate containers for testing Open AD Kit
issues_comment_text: @xmfcx Once the containers have been created, I am happy to help out with the testing part of this issue.

issues_title: Create separate containers for testing Open AD Kit
issues_comment_text:
# Required nodes

In order to list the required nodes for the containers, I am trying to use @kenji-miyake -san's tool from https://github.com/orgs/autowarefoundation/discussions/2581

The tool is private for now but I'm working in cooperation with him to resolve some [issues](https://github.com/kenji-miyake/ros_component_diagram_generator/issues/6) on the package.

With the tool, I will hopefully have a list of all the nodes that are launched with the main launch files.

# Building the docker image manually

Right now I am trying to use this [build.sh](https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/blob/main/docker/build.sh) to build the docker image but every time I tried, I got some connectivity issues and every time I restarted, it failed at some point and takes a very long time to retry. I will investigate this further.

I will try to build the container without buildx thingy, maybe add more layers to the image, also will consult to @kenji-miyake on this.

issues_comment_text:

https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/pkgs/container/autoware-universe/26944787?tag=humble-latest-cuda

issues_title: CUDA environment is broken when I run a docker container with rocker
issues_comment_text:
I found the problem is because of the env `NVIDIA_DRIVER_CAPABILITIES`.

To confirm that, run the following command.

```bash
rocker --nvidia --x11 --user --env NVIDIA_DRIVER_CAPABILITIES="" -- ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:humble-latest-cuda

# Or
rocker --nvidia --x11 --user --env NVIDIA_DRIVER_CAPABILITIES=compute,utility,graphics -- ghcr.io/autowarefoundation/autoware-universe:humble-latest-cuda
```

I'll investigate this behavior more in detail and fix it.

After that, I will check it works with cuda11.6.

https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/pull/154#issuecomment-1099745019

https://developer.download.nvidia.com/compute/cuda/repos/ubuntu2004/x86_64/
https://developer.download.nvidia.com/compute/cuda/repos/ubuntu2004/sbsa/

I've created a helper tool to find CUDA versions.
https://github.com/kenji-miyake/find-cuda-versions

Now we can find if there are any corresponding versions to a certain CUDA version.

```sh-session
$ pip install git+https://github.com/kenji-miyake/find-cuda-versions.git
$ find-cuda-versions --cuda 11.6
[cudnn x86_64]
8.4.0.27-1+cuda11.6

[cudnn sbsa]
8.4.0.27-1+cuda11.6

[tensorrt x86_64]

[tensorrt sbsa]
```
This pull request has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity.

Updated to 11.6 in the `humble` branch.
https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.ai/blob/d2feaef806f93ceb60ae50d49ae98d904fef3e09/amd64.env#L5

But we should also consider updating to 11.7 because 11.6 isn't released to ubuntu 22.04 repo.
https://developer.download.nvidia.com/compute/cuda/repos/ubuntu2204/x86_64/

Currently, we use 20.04 repo with ubuntu 22.04 because 11.7 doesn't have corresponding cuDNN and TensorRT yet.

issues_title: Vulkan driver fails to detect GPU
issues_comment_text:
The nvidia vulkan library needs to be registered for it to be discovered when running a vulkan program.
In Autoware.Auto we were adding the necessary file to the docker environment here: https://gitlab.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.auto/AutowareAuto/-/blob/e3e26be1ab4b822996df60f261d031d7924f20ac/tools/ade_image/Dockerfile#L100

Replicating this in the .universe environment (changing /etc/vulkan/ to /usr/share/vulkan/ to match were the other icd files are in this case)
```sh
wget https://gitlab.com/nvidia/container-images/vulkan/raw/master/nvidia_icd.json
sudo mv nvidia_icd.json /usr/share/vulkan/icd.d/
```
the vulkaninfo output changes to an error, but the actual vulkan capability works in the program I was testing.
A fast way to get vulkaninfo to work correctly is to use the "--privileged" flag when launching rocker/docker (and still getting the icd file), but I'm not sure if it would have an impact on actual programs using vulkan.

issues_title: Consider how we should write copyright notices
issues_comment_text:
My proposal:

### For new files

Rule:

- Prepare `NOTICE` and use `Copyright yyyy The Autoware Contributors`.

Rationale:

- As LF says, We don't want to pay a lot of maintenance costs for updating copyright notations.

### For existing files

Rule:

- Accept the as-is style.
- We can change the copyright notation to `Copyright yyyy The Autoware Contributors`. if we can agree with the original authors to do so.

Rationale:

- Since we'll clean up the architecture for Autoware Core, we don't have to care about the existing Universe code so much.
- (I guess) We can't change the copyright notations without some agreements with the original authors.

### For all files

Rule:

- Add `SPDX-License-Identifier`.
- Will accept any other proposals in the future.

Rationale:

- SPDX is useful for automatically analyzing licenses.
- Since we are not legal professionals, there are a lot of things we don't know.

issues_title: Consider how we should write copyright notices

issues_title: Consider how we should write copyright notices
issues_comment_text:
> (I guess) We can't change the copyright notations without some agreements with the original authors.

For this, I think it's a good idea to agree with people who want to write their names to `NOTICE`, that "if you want to write your name here, you have to remove your name from each Copyright notation or agree that the maintainers will remove them.", how about this?

(Seeing [here](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/blob/184591aeeb5a531f2315c3d7cddcd199c87ecb2c/libcxx/CREDITS.TXT), `CREDITS.TXT` might be the correct place to write contributors? :thinking: -> [This](https://infra.apache.org/licensing-howto.html#mod-notice) says `Copyright notifications which have been relocated, rather than removed, from source files must be preserved in NOTICE.` )

issues_title: [Documentation] Commit message guidelines for cleaner commit history
issues_comment_text:
When exploring in which commit the changes have been made to interested parts, if the commit message has many lines it makes us harder to find what we are looking for. 
Let's say someone made changes to the localization module, modified the NDT's optimization function, and I want to improve the functionality. 
If commit message was like

```
Improve NDT
* tmp 
* update
* remove a for loop
* ...
```

I can not obtain any information from there.
If every commit message was like this I cannot even find in which commit the changes I want to refer to have been made.

issues_title: [Documentation] Commit message guidelines for cleaner commit history
issues_comment_text:
I'll close this because there is no response and I think it's a problem of tool usage.

We use https://www.conventionalcommits.org/en/v1.0.0/ and `Squash merge` now. I'll write guideline documents about that and it's tracked in https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware-documentation/issues/6.

@IshitaTakeshi Please describe for what reasons you need `kvaser-interface`.
Also, is it impossible to replace it with https://github.com/autowarefoundation/ros2_socketcan?

It seems Kvaser devices supports SocketCAN.
https://www.kvaser.com/socketcan-support-for-kvaser-devices-updated/
We have never used `ros2_socketcan` on autonomostuff vehicle, so we have to test it on the real vehicle before migrating to `ros2_socketcan`.

Okay, then I think we should test it. If it won't work we'll import the role from here.
https://github.com/tier4/AutowareArchitectureProposal.proj/blob/474da436880f93bd59d87107bd9d83254b0cd9b3/ansible/roles/pacmod/tasks/kvaser_library.yml

Also, we have to do a trick to use kvaser usb as socketcan interface.
```
sudo modprobe kvaser_usb
<- unplug and plug kvaser usb here
sudo ip link set can0 up type can bitrate 50000
```
Thank you. I think it can be supported by some setup scripts for real vehicles.

This is the reason to add kvaser-interface to the requirements. When launching the logging simulator it says that kvaser_interface cannot be found.

```
root@87a3663a4a81:/autoware# source install/setup.bash 
root@87a3663a4a81:/autoware# ros2 launch tier4_autoware_launch logging_simulator.launch.xml sensor_model:=aip_xx1 map_path:=/dataset/kashiwanoha/ vehicle_model:=lexus
[INFO] [launch]: All log files can be found below /root/.ros/log/2022-01-19-09-21-13-992999-87a3663a4a81-60
[INFO] [launch]: Default logging verbosity is set to INFO
Task exception was never retrieved
future: <Task finished name='Task-2' coro=<LaunchService._process_one_event() done, defined at /opt/ros/galactic/lib/python3.8/site-packages/launch/launch_service.py:226> exception=PackageNotFoundError("package 'kvaser_interface' not found,
```

Why do you need `kvaser-interface` for the launch file?
Do you use a physical CAN in the simulation?

Not sure so I grep-ed in the workspace directory and got the following

```
# find . -type f | xargs grep kvaser_interface
./src/vehicle/lexus_launch/launch/pacmod3.launch.py:            package='kvaser_interface',
./install/lexus_description/share/lexus_description/launch/pacmod3.launch.py:            package='kvaser_interface',
```

Apparently pacmod3 requires it.
I know it has the dependency, but my question is, why do you have to launch the node in the simulation?

What node do you refer to?

My current task is to improve the localization accuracy and availability so basically I don't need to launch all the nodes under the logging simulator, but for me, who doesn't know that much about the Autoware architecture, it is easier to launch the logging simulator than disabling unnecessary nodes.

> What node do you refer to?

Probably this?
https://github.com/tier4/lexus_description.iv/blob/4a3a06e297f85a737d2b5879b508843b2998038a/launch/pacmod3_with_kvaser-node-launch.py

> but for me, who doesn't know that much about the Autoware architecture,

I believe it's better that you'll get familiar with Autoware and do appropriate handling!
I guess, for example, we need to add an option of whether to launch `kvaser-interface`, to [this file](https://github.com/tier4/lexus_description.iv/blob/4a3a06e297f85a737d2b5879b508843b2998038a/launch/vehicle_interface.launch.xml).

Okay, but at least as an OSS it should be much better the logging simulator always works fine so when merging the Dockerfile to the default branch we should disable the node depending on `kvaser-interface` (or install `kvaser-interface`), otherwise users will regard autoware as just useless.

Acceptance Criteria:

- [ ] Consider replacing `kvaser-interface` by `ros2_socketcan`.
We need to evaluate `ros2_socketcan` with Kvaser devices to do that.

Or,
- [ ] Consider removing `kvaser-interface` from `logging_simulator.launch.xml`.
Essentially, no hardware is required for the simulation.

> Acceptance Criteria:
> 
> * [ ]  Consider replacing `kvaser-interface` by `ros2_socketcan`.
>   We need to evaluate `ros2_socketcan` with Kvaser devices to do that.
> 
> Or,
> 
> * [ ]  Consider removing `kvaser-interface` from `logging_simulator.launch.xml`.
>   Essentially, no hardware is required for the simulation.
Maybe we should remove `kvaser-interface` from `logging_simulator.launch.xml` and using ros2_socketcan. We can setup a fake socket can interface when doing simulation.
Since I've created https://github.com/autowarefoundation/sample_vehicle_launch that doesn't depend on `kvaser` or `pacmod`, I'll close this.

Hi, any updates on this issue ?

@hakuturu583 Can we use `embree_vendor` package on arm CPU ?

> @hakuturu583 Can we use embree_vendor package on arm CPU ?

Yes, I tested on qemu and it works.

Hi @hakuturu583,
 I've tried with Scenario Simulator **master** branch and [embree_vendor](https://github.com/OUXT-Polaris/embree_vendor). It uses embree version 4.2.0 and when I try to do:
 `colcon build --cmake-args -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release --packages-up-to simple_sensor_simulator`
 
I got following error on compilation:
`error: ‘RTCIntersectContext’ has not been declared`

I also checked with the original Embree version 4.0 changelog and it says:
`RTCIntersectContext is renamed to RTCRayQuery context and most members moved to
    new RTCIntersectArguments and RTCOccludedArguments structures.`
   
So it appears that embree version 4.x is not fit for Scenario simulator. How should I proceed do you have any suggestions ? 

Thanks in advance.

I just checked installed embree apt package in my amd64 platform. It looks like I have version 3.12.2 installed.
May be you could try changing [this line](https://github.com/OUXT-Polaris/embree_vendor/blob/7cd96dd0a938e93a4bdc4f09089ef070f0a407ad/CMakeLists.txt#L32C13-L32C19) to `v3.12.2`.

I tried building with `v3.12.2` and it requires libTBB version `2021.1.1` and is incompatible with `2021.5.0` that we have on Ubuntu22/arm64. Also tried version `v3.13.5` and it failed with ` error: unrecognized command-line option ‘-msse2’` seems like the flag incompatibility with arm64.

I was able to build on arm with the following workaround:
1. Use Embree 3.13.5 and cherry-pick https://github.com/embree/embree/commit/82ca6b5ccb7abe0403a658a0e079926478f04cb1 as mentioned in [this issue](https://github.com/embree/embree/issues/383#issuecomment-1453490760). I've created a fork of embree_vendor with the fix so you can use the following:
```
cd autoware/src/universe/external
git clone -b v3.13.5_arm https://github.com/mitsudome-r/embree_vendor
```
2. Modify simple_sensor_simulator's dependency in package.xml to use embree_vendor instead of embree.
3. Even with the above fix, I still had errors from Eigen in openscenario_visualization package related to this [issue](https://gitlab.com/libeigen/eigen/-/issues/2326). I added this warning as exception in the compile option as a quick fix.

For 2 and 3, you can checkout my fork:
```
cd autoware/src/simulator/scenario_simulator
git remote add https://github.com/mitsudome-r/scenario_simulator_v2
git fetch mitsudome-r
git checkout arm
```
Related Issue: https://github.com/tier4/scenario_simulator_v2/issues/1094

> I was able to build on arm with the following workaround:
> 
> 1. Use Embree 3.13.5 and cherry-pick [embree/embree@82ca6b5](https://github.com/embree/embree/commit/82ca6b5ccb7abe0403a658a0e079926478f04cb1) as mentioned in [this issue](https://github.com/embree/embree/issues/383#issuecomment-1453490760). I've created a fork of embree_vendor with the fix so you can use the following:
> 
> ```
> cd autoware/src/universe/external
> git clone -b v3.13.5_arm https://github.com/mitsudome-r/embree_vendor
> ```
> 
> 2. Modify simple_sensor_simulator's dependency in package.xml to use embree_vendor instead of embree.
> 3. Even with the above fix, I still had errors from Eigen in openscenario_visualization package related to this [issue](https://gitlab.com/libeigen/eigen/-/issues/2326). I added this warning as exception in the compile option as a quick fix.
> 
> For 2 and 3, you can checkout my fork:
> 
> ```
> cd autoware/src/simulator/scenario_simulator
> git remote add https://github.com/mitsudome-r/scenario_simulator_v2
> git fetch mitsudome-r
> git checkout arm
> ```

Thanks @mitsudome-r that solved the issue.

@kenji-miyake 
Here is the report:

[autowarefoundation](https://github.com/autowarefoundation) organization has a [GitHub Actions Runner](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/hosting-your-own-runners/about-self-hosted-runners) registered with a name `AutowareFoundationGithubActionsRunner`.

This runner runs on an AWS `t4g.xlarge` instance. [Amazon EC2 T4g instances are powered by Arm-based AWS Graviton2 processors.](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/t4/)

It has 4 vCPUs and 16GiB RAM.

This binary was installed on it: https://github.com/actions/runner/releases/download/v2.276.1/actions-runner-linux-arm64-2.276.1.tar.gz

issues_title: Storage space of ARM self-hosted runner is probably small
issues_comment_text:
Also for x86_64 jobs we are using [GitHub-hosted runners](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-github-hosted-runners/about-github-hosted-runners):

![chrome_2022-01-14_21-12-13](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10751153/149564595-be89d035-18b0-478c-ae7b-1ae14b96fe9a.png)

Hardware specification for Windows and Linux virtual machines:

2-core CPU
7 GB of RAM memory
14 GB of SSD disk space
 
And I think these machines probably won't be enough for building the Autoware and we will need to look into self-hosted ephemeral runners for these too.

We could add but I think we should first try to reduce the space we are using. This is ok for single runner but for parallel runners it'll cost too much, not scalable. In autoware.auto 30gb total space for entire machine was enough.

issues_title: Storage space of ARM self-hosted runner is probably small

issues_title: Storage space of ARM self-hosted runner is probably small
issues_comment_text: We won't use cuda on CI, we should make it optional.

issues_title: Storage space of ARM self-hosted runner is probably small
issues_comment_text:
If so, we can't check the build of some perception modules in `autoware.universe`, is that okay?
Also, could you tell me why do you think making it optional is good?

issues_title: Storage space of ARM self-hosted runner is probably small
issues_comment_text:
> If so, we can't check the build of some perception modules in `autoware.universe`, is that okay? Also, could you tell me why do you think making it optional is good?

The CI machines don't have Nvidia gpus and CUDA only works on nvidia gpus so we couldn't check them anyway.

Instances with gpus are much more expensive, we could set them to be checked with lower frequency if needed.

issues_title: Storage space of ARM self-hosted runner is probably small

> Instances with gpus are much more expensive, we could set them to be checked with lower frequency if needed.

We don't need GPUs.

issues_title: Adoption of Changelog Enforcer GitHub Action in Autoware Repositories
issues_comment_text:
## github-changelog-generator

There is also an automated way of doing it using [github-changelog-generator](https://github.com/github-changelog-generator/github-changelog-generator#github-changelog-generator-).
- It generates [CHANGELOG.md files like this](https://github.com/github-changelog-generator/github-changelog-generator/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md).
- Related Github Action: https://github.com/marketplace/actions/generate-changelog

## Github Releases

There is also [Github Releases](https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-github/about-releases).
- [automatically-generated-release-notes](https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/releasing-projects-on-github/automatically-generated-release-notes#creating-automatically-generated-release-notes-for-a-new-release)

I will investigate these options more and also share my findings. Please don't hesitate to add your inputs.

---
**Edit:**

---

## semantic-release

https://github.com/semantic-release/semantic-release#-semantic-release

> semantic-release automates the whole package release workflow including: determining the next version number, generating the release notes, and publishing the package.

## clerk

This is my favorite so far. :sparkling_heart: 

> Clerk ensures that release notes can be generated from PRs by looking for a release note in the PR description. You can add a note to your PR by adding a single line to its description beginning with `notes: `.

- https://github.com/electron/clerk
- https://github.com/apps/release-clerk

**Example Changelog:** https://github.com/electron/electron/releases

**Example PR:** https://github.com/electron/electron/pull/40536

This looks like the best mix of automation and manual provision. The developers don't need to touch the CHANGELOG.md file.

Developers just use the commit messages with the Conventional Commit style as usual and just add Release Notes section for each PR and rest is automated.

issues_comment_text:
@TakaHoribe thank you!

> is it required to modify the changelog file in all PRs? Or, the changelog is updated automatically from the PR's description?

For the https://github.com/marketplace/actions/changelog-enforcer mentioned in the first issue, you must manually edit the changelog.

But if we use https://github.com/googleapis/release-please#release-please then it is completely automated (from Commit Message.

It generates ChangeLogs like this: https://github.com/googleapis/gapic-generator/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md

[release-please](https://github.com/googleapis/release-please) seems very popular and also maintained by Google(?) for now it is the most promising option. And it requires the least additional effort from the contributors.
