issues_title: colcon warning when using development docker for 'velodyne_msgs'
issues_comment_text:
Hello @felixf4xu 

Thanks for reporting this. This is a benign warning, at least for the current state of this project.

## Simple terminology

In ROS, an overlay is a workspace that is built on top of an underlay.
The underlay typically contains packages installed from binary distributions (like the ROS base installations), while the overlay is where you are developing or compiling additional packages.

## What is this warning **not** about?

This warning is not (at least for now) about whether:
- the package will be built or not.
- the package is will be overridden or not.

> ```console
> ~$ colcon build --help
>   --allow-overriding PKG_NAME [PKG_NAME ...]
>                        Allow building packages that exist in underlay workspaces
> ```

The package will be built and prioritized whether this warning shown or not.

**Detailed info about overriding packages with colcon:** https://colcon.readthedocs.io/en/released/user/overriding-packages.html

Here is an example with and without overriding:

### Without overriding (default)
```console
mfc@mfc-leo:~/projects/autoware$ source /opt/ros/humble/setup.bash
mfc@mfc-leo:~/projects/autoware$ colbu --cmake-args -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo -DCMAKE_EXPORT_COMPILE_COMMANDS=1  --packages-select  velodyne_msgs
[1.509s] WARNING:colcon.colcon_core.package_selection:Some selected packages are already built in one or more underlay workspaces:
	'velodyne_msgs' is in: /opt/ros/humble
If a package in a merged underlay workspace is overridden and it installs headers, then all packages in the overlay must sort their include directories by workspace order. Failure to do so may result in build failures or undefined behavior at run time.
If the overridden package is used by another package in any underlay, then the overriding package in the overlay must be API and ABI compatible or undefined behavior at run time may occur.

If you understand the risks and want to override a package anyways, add the following to the command line:
	--allow-overriding velodyne_msgs

This may be promoted to an error in a future release of colcon-override-check.
Starting >>> velodyne_msgs
Finished <<< velodyne_msgs [3.23s]                     

Summary: 1 package finished [4.47s]
mfc@mfc-leo:~/projects/autoware$ source install/setup.bash
mfc@mfc-leo:~/projects/autoware$ ros2 pkg prefix velodyne_msgs
/home/mfc/projects/autoware/install/velodyne_msgs
```

### With overriding

```console
mfc@mfc-leo:~/projects/autoware$ source /opt/ros/humble/setup.bash
mfc@mfc-leo:~/projects/autoware$ colcon build --symlink-install  --cmake-args -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo -DCMAKE_EXPORT_COMPILE_COMMANDS=1  --packages-select velodyne_msgs --allow-overriding velodyne_msgs
Starting >>> velodyne_msgs
Finished <<< velodyne_msgs [0.62s]                     

Summary: 1 package finished [1.84s]
mfc@mfc-leo:~/projects/autoware$ source install/setup.bash
mfc@mfc-leo:~/projects/autoware$ ros2 pkg prefix velodyne_msgs
/home/mfc/projects/autoware/install/velodyne_msgs
```

### Analysis

So whether we override or not, `velodyne_msgs` in the local workspace will have higher priority.

There might be problems that might arise that I don't know. But so far I've never had a problem from having a package overridden in the workspace.

## What could go wrong if we do a dangerous override?

Let's say we have the following packages:
**M1**: distributed with ros, underlay package (it's a ros message package)
**M2**: overridden in local workspace, overlay package (it's a ros message package)
**B**: distributed with ros, depends on **M1**
**C**: local package, publishes **M2** message

In the local workspace, if **C** publishes **M2** message, **B** will not be able to subscribe to it. This is because **B** is compiled with **M1** message, and **M1** and **M2** are not compatible.

This is just a simple scenario I've come up with, you can find more details and dangers here:
- https://colcon.readthedocs.io/en/released/user/overriding-packages.html#override-every-package-that-depends-on-the-one-you-want-to-override

## What is being overridden?

- (underlay) https://github.com/ros-drivers/velodyne/tree/ros2/velodyne_msgs
- (overlay) https://github.com/tier4/nebula/tree/main/nebula_messages/velodyne_msgs

These are identical.

@drwnz why did you not use the upstream binary package for this?

## Steps to take

- Maybe we can write a short explanation for this on the documentation.
- We could remove the package from the nebula driver. (since they are identical).
- We could use a different name for the nebula driver package.

Hello @DeeKayG and welcome to the Autoware project!

I know it's a bit un-intuitive but when creating a new PR, you should click on "Small change" or "Standard change" and fill in the information.
More info can be found in here: https://autowarefoundation.github.io/autoware-documentation/main/contributing/pull-request-guidelines/#example

I've pasted in the small change option and edited your PR, you don't need to do this anymore for this PR.
You can edit the description now.

Could you rename your first commit message to `feat: add universe_dbw_bridge package` please?

Hmm I was confused for a moment, this change should be proposed into https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe not here. Could you create this PR targeting there please?

The reason:
- https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware is a meta repository, has the ansible scripts for installation and the main workspace structure.
- https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe has most of the functional code.

issues_title: feat(ansible): add yabloc archive extraction to andsible script
issues_comment_text:
YabLoc does not require the models during compilation. The `model_float32.pb` is loaded when performing initial pose estimation after launching Autoware. 

If the model file is not found, non-DNN methods will be used for initial pose estimation. (This is not accurate, but initial position estimation will complete.)

issues_comment_text: @angry-crab do you have some idea about this issue ?
I have this issue also ,did you resolve it?
I guess you are using a different version of TensorRT. Maybe you could try to upgrade it.

> 我猜你使用的是不同版本的 TensorRT。也许你可以尝试升级它。

I installed the tensorrt environment according to this configuration https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/pull/3084#discussion_r1160428947

> ❯ find-cuda-versions --cuda 12.0 --os ubuntu2204
> [cudnn x86_64]
> 8.8.0.121-1+cuda12.0
> 8.8.1.3-1+cuda12.0
> 
> [cudnn sbsa]
> 8.8.0.121-1+cuda12.0
> 8.8.1.3-1+cuda12.0
> 
> [nvinfer x86_64]
> 8.6.0.12-1+cuda12.0
> 
> [nvinfer sbsa]
> 
> [tensorrt x86_64]
> 8.6.0.12-1+cuda12.0
> 
> [tensorrt sbsa]

> I have this issue also ,did you resolve it?

I switched the cuda environment ，everything is fine now

> 1. cuda_version=11.8
> 2. cudnn_version=8.7.0.84-1+cuda11.8
> 3. tensorrt_version=8.6.1.6-1+cuda11.8

If you want to do like me, you can execute the following command
```
sudo apt-get -y install cuda-11-8
sudo apt-get install libcudnn8=8.7.0.84-1+cuda11.8 libcudnn8-dev=8.7.0.84-1+cuda11.8
sudo apt-mark hold libcudnn8 libcudnn8-dev

sudo apt-get install libnvinfer-headers-dev=8.6.1.6-1+cuda11.8 libnvinfer-headers-plugin-dev=8.6.1.6-1+cuda11.8 libnvinfer8=8.6.1.6-1+cuda11.8 libnvonnxparsers8=8.6.1.6-1+cuda11.8 libnvparsers8=8.6.1.6-1+cuda11.8 libnvinfer-plugin8=8.6.1.6-1+cuda11.8 libnvinfer-dev=8.6.1.6-1+cuda11.8 libnvonnxparsers-dev=8.6.1.6-1+cuda11.8 libnvparsers-dev=8.6.1.6-1+cuda11.8 libnvinfer-plugin-dev=8.6.1.6-1+cuda11.8

sudo apt-mark hold libnvinfer-headers-dev libnvinfer-headers-plugin-dev libnvinfer8 libnvonnxparsers8 libnvparsers8 libnvinfer-plugin8 libnvinfer-dev libnvonnxparsers-dev libnvparsers-dev libnvinfer-plugin-dev
```

issues_comment_text: i have this issue also ,are you resolve it?

I opened a merged request that should fix the issue: https://gitlab.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.auto/AutowareAuto/-/merge_requests/1388
I cannot test it myself so please let me know whether it solves the issue or not.

Thanks!

Yes, this solves the compilation of `vesc_ackermann`.

Compilation of another package (`mpc_controller`) fails, but I guess I should file a separate issue for that.

I solve the problem by changing the function as:
speed_to_erpm_gain_ = declare_parameter<double>("speed_to_erpm_gain",speed_to_erpm_gain_);
The main problem is that the instructions on gitlab seem to be outdated and that the instructions on github should be taken.

Try modifying the projection type in lanelet2_map_loader to `local` from the default `MGRS`
https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware_launch/blob/c6312c7dcaa8fdcf17b54c11953b2c23861cd577/autoware_launch/config/map/lanelet2_map_loader.param.yaml#L3

We have made change to the projector in https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe/pull/3492, and user must choose the local projection type explicitly if the map is using local coordinates from pointcloud.

Thank you @mitsudome-r for your response. I have made the changes from the default `MGRS` to `local` as you suggest, and now it fixed the issue that I faced.

I will now close this issue.

The awsim stable branch is a branch that may be modified and that I personally would like to delete in the future. (But, the main branch is fine)
Therefore, I think it's worth discussing whether to specify the awsim stable branch or not.

issues_comment_text:

I think that the message type should have at least a bool variable. Any other information you need (e.g. text message)?

issues_title: Create API to request manual operation
issues_comment_text: Can we use an existing RTC(Request to corporate) Interface?

issues_title: Create API to request manual operation
issues_comment_text:
> Can we use an existing RTC(Request to corporate) Interface?

@yukkysaito RTC is a function that the  operator supports Autoware decisions during autonomous driving, so it is assumed that autonomous driving can continue. On the other hand, since this is a function that requests mode switching when autonomous driving cannot continue, we concluded that it would be better to use a different API in [this PR](https://github.com/tier4/tier4_ad_api_adaptor/pull/95) discussion.

issues_title: Create API to request manual operation
issues_comment_text:
@isamu-takagi In RTI, there are situations such as OR for a stuck vehicle or an emergency vehicle passing by.
In such cases, I think it would be better to notify the operator of what caused the request for OR, so I think it would be better to have a section that describes what happened.

issues_title: Create API to request manual operation
issues_comment_text: @yabuta Thank you for comment. Add message field. Also, I feel that  a stuck vehicle or an emergency vehicle passing have different priorities when supporting multiple vehicles remotely, so I changed from bool to uint to support that.

issues_title: Clean unused dependencies to improve build time
issues_comment_text:
This is a great initiative! Thanks!

In the exceptions section of the script, is it easy to add a list of verified dependencies per package? So that if people check a particular "unused dependency" and verify it is in fact used, that it can be excepted from the search in the future?

issues_title: Clean unused dependencies to improve build time
issues_comment_text:
@simon-t4 This is just a PoC script. By default, I just look for any `#include <dep_name/.*>` in the C/C++ source files. But as you can see, there are quite a few listed "exceptions" (and I may have missed a few). Most exceptions are system libraries (e.g. `libboost-dev` -> `#include <boost/.*>`), but there are also "special" dependencies that won't be used in the source code (e.g. `rosidl_default_generators` brings cmake macros). It is not difficult to add more cases/exceptions to avoid false positives.

To answer your question precisely, I have not met a case where a dependency is listed in the `package.xml` yet not found anywhere in any of the packages files. But even if it was the case, you could always add a simple rule such as `[[ "$dep" == "SomeDependency" ]] && [[ "$pkg" == "SomePkg" ]] && continue`. At the end of the day, the script is just a tool, it does not have to be "clean".

issues_title: Clean unused dependencies to improve build time
issues_comment_text:
I have updated the script above a bit and quickly fixed all reported dependencies. Then checked release build time before/after on my machine:

```bash
$ colcon build --symlink-install --event-handlers=console_cohesion+ --cmake-args -DCMAKE_EXPORT_COMPILE_COMMANDS=1 -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo -DBUILD_TESTING=False -DCMAKE_C_FLAGS='-fdiagnostics-color' -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS='-fdiagnostics-color' -GNinja
```

Before:
```
real	42m21.522s
user	257m55.620s
sys	17m22.792s
```

After:
```
real	42m17.404s
user	244m15.675s
sys	16m57.653s
```

The `real` time is not impacted much (not exactly sure why), but you can see `user` and `sys` times are reduced by a decent amount: 275m17 seconds of "cpu time" (user+sys) after compared to 287m17s before. That is +5% faster, just by removing unused stuff...!

There are a lot of `package.xml` to clean, any help to create PRs is welcomed :)

issues_title: Clean unused dependencies to improve build time
issues_comment_text:
@VRichardJP Good work!
I haven't looked through all the items in the list, but at least for lanelet2_extension, it should be using `geographiclib`. Likewise, there could be some non-ROS package (what you call "system dependencies" in your script) that shouldn't be removed from the dependencies.

issues_title: Clean unused dependencies to improve build time
Clean unused dependencies to improve build time
issues_comment_text: I would like to take on this and how may I start. A little example would be helpful

issues_title: Replace binary images with lighter SVG counterparts
Replace binary images with lighter SVG counterparts
issues_comment_text:
For example,
Following file:

https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe/blob/main/planning/behavior_path_planner/image/avoidance/avoidance_design.fig1.drawio.svg

Has no reason to be this large.

But it has many binary images inside which can be replaced with vector images.

issues_title: Replace binary images with lighter SVG counterparts
issues_comment_text:
I don't know a thing about graphic software, but from a quick google it seems Inkscape has quick auto-vectorization tool:

https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe/blob/main/planning/behavior_path_planner/image/lane_change/lane_change-enable_collision_check_at_prepare_phase.png

- Path > Trace Bitmap...
- Tab: Multicolor
- Detection Mode: Color
- Remove Background

Took me 30 seconds (sorry for dark mode users):
![g170](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18645627/235017530-6c1a4399-2e54-4851-aecb-6ff804bd8b63.svg)

Size before: 7MB
Size after: 650KB

I don't know if it is a very clean SVG, in particular text is not stored as text, but it could be a quick and effective way to reduce image size. The better way would be to have access to the original files.

issues_title: Replace binary images with lighter SVG counterparts
issues_comment_text:
> https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe/blob/main/planning/behavior_path_planner/image/avoidance/avoidance_design.fig1.drawio.svg
> Has no reason to be this large.

I'm not sure, but it might have some meta data for re-editing in `draw.io`.

issues_title: Replace binary images with lighter SVG counterparts
issues_comment_text:
> @kenji-miyake I think we should add a rule in documentation to not allow binary image contributions.

@xmfcx I remember you said we can consider utilizing `git-lfs` for images.
Did you find any problem with `git-lfs` and change your mind?

> (I don't know if it's practical to add a CI check for this.)

If we really disallow image files, I think checking on CI is good.

issues_title: Replace binary images with lighter SVG counterparts
issues_comment_text:
@VRichardJP thanks, I didn't know Inkscape could do it too.

I could get following in Illustrator following https://helpx.adobe.com/illustrator/using/image-trace.html

![Asset 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10751153/235068956-474bd10d-30e2-4912-9f4d-3b76a0483e06.svg)

> I'm not sure, but it might have some meta data for re-editing in draw.io

@kenji-miyake it's likely. Because when I opened the file with Illustrator and just saved it back without doing anything, it got reduced to 25KB.

![avoidance_design fig1 drawio](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10751153/235068289-a0cd479c-76e7-4041-8cbc-14bbce5ee5b2.svg)

We can still utilize git-lfs, but just for light vector files, it might not be necessary.

issues_title: Replace binary images with lighter SVG counterparts
issues_comment_text: @xmfcx By the way, how critical is this issue? Do you have any specific problems caused by the repository size?

issues_title: Replace binary images with lighter SVG counterparts
issues_comment_text:
> By the way, how critical is this issue? Do you have any specific problems caused by the repository size?

I'd say it has normal priority. Keeping repo small in general is a good practice. And earlier we do this, better it is. Because these binary files keep making the .git folder larger and larger with no return.

I've realized this while investigating why the autoware folder was so large. Then realized these images and it'd be a good thing to do if anyone would like to spare some time.

It'd be the best if people who contributed these files put here the lighter versions instead, since we might lose some quality otherwise.

issues_title: Replace binary images with lighter SVG counterparts
issues_comment_text:
> @xmfcx I remember you said we can consider utilizing `git-lfs` for images.
> Did you find any problem with git-lfs and change your mind?

We had a discussion with the Autoware Planning & Control team in the [WG meeting](https://github.com/orgs/autowarefoundation/discussions/3558).

@kenji-miyake 

The common agreement was that the draw.io metadata information (the binary blob) in the files are important for the team. We should keep them.

And to allow this, I had 2 solutions:
- Add `git-lfs` support for the image and binary files. (my preference)
- Replace the `.svg` files with smaller versions. But collect and host the original `.drawio.svg` files in some google drive, have links to them in the documentation. (too complicated and hard to maintain)

@esteve do you think adding `git-lfs` tracking to the generic image files in the middle of repository timeline might have any unknown side effects?

I would like to go with this option but we also need to update the documentation, maybe ansible scripts, maybe for certain CI actions (like mk-docs generation) to have this support.

issues_title: Replace binary images with lighter SVG counterparts
issues_comment_text:
> @esteve do you think adding `git-lfs` tracking to the generic image files in the middle of repository timeline might have any unknown side effects?

I don't know of any side effects, but I agree with using `git-lfs` for storing the `.svg` files.
I have a mistake. sorry

issues_comment_text:
I removed the local parser for lanelet_extension

the local parser will be in map_loader
https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe/pull/3492

issues_title: Add option to lanelet2_map_loader for local coordinates
Add option to lanelet2_map_loader for local coordinates
issues_comment_text:
> The task: Add dummy projector to lanelet2_extension

This task is not important. Currently, [if a local type is used, it is overwritten with local coordinates after being projected with MGRS](https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe/blob/b255111b7b11df532a11817134c33ca36c92b498/map/map_loader/src/lanelet2_map_loader/lanelet2_map_loader_node.cpp#L102-L115), so there is a bit of processing waste.


Also, there may be cases where only some positions are overwritten with local coordinates. In this case, it is better to be able to specify a sub-projection type when using local projections.

issues_title: Add option to lanelet2_map_loader for local coordinates
issues_comment_text:
>Also, there may be cases where only some positions are overwritten with local coordinates. In this case, it is better to be able to specify a sub-projection type when using local projections.

Changed to use dummy projector. I will consider adding the above cases if necessary.
https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe/pull/5866

Let the user pass the "autoware_data" folder directory to the ansible script. (ref: https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/blob/main/setup-dev-env.sh ) (default: `~/autoware_data/` as suggested by @esteve )
Then ONNX files will be downloaded into:

```
.../autoware_data/package_name/map.pcd
.../autoware_data/package_name/map.josm ?
.../autoware_data/package_name/model1.onnx
```

Details in: https://github.com/orgs/autowarefoundation/discussions/3649#discussioncomment-6475228

Once this PR is tested and merged,

We can modify the launch files to point to these new files.

And we can proceed to remove existing cmake references.

issues_title: feat: use ansible to download ONNX files
issues_comment_text: @xmfcx thanks :slightly_smiling_face:

@xmfcx I think pacmod could be moved out easily, but as you say Velodyne is essential to our architecture, so I'm not sure if it should be moved out. The Tamagawa IMU driver doesn't seem to be used much, though. Only two packages depend on it: `sample_sensor_kit_launch` and `awsim_sensor_kit_launch`

@xmfcx I'm sorry for joining late. Explaining the background, these are from TIER IV's reference vehicle/sensor_kit.

I think splitting repos or just removing some is okay, but there are several things to be discussed:
1. Which perspective to divide

Do you really want to split drivers? Or do you want to split the entire sensor components? I'm not sure which is better. 

> Since not every vehicle will use all the drivers, it's better for them to have a separate driver.repos file.

Seeing this purpose, I feel like you want to split the sensor components that aren't related to your vehicle.

> This way when people fork autoware, it's easier for them to disable these repositories.

For this, I think users can do it with the current configuration because they are under the `sensor_component` section. :thinking:
Could you please show me some concrete examples?

2. Dependency

We might need to fix some dependencies before splitting them out.

---

Anyway, I'd like to clarify the background and issues more.
Honestly, I feel that the current proposal might be a bit short-sighted.
So could you share your troubles in more detail with me?

@xmfcx 
Could you share more detail about the purpose of this issue?
- Is it to create new repos file to list up Autoware-supported sensor drivers?, or
- Do you just want to remove the need of installing unnecessary drivers?

If  latter is the case, I think we can just remove Tamagawa-imu and pacmod-interface drivers since they are not used in tutorials anyways.

So, I have thought about this more generally and here are the things I'd like to achieve:

- Users shouldn't be forced to build drivers that they won't use.
- The drivers should be tested in the repository through the CI to keep compatible.
- Some drivers are essential, like the nebula driver.

For this, I will separate out the following:
- `pacmod_interface`
- `tamagawa_imu_driver`
 
into a different `.repos` file called `extra-packages.repos`.

Will modify the CI to pull them along with the others, build and test as usual.

The users will download the usual `autoware.repos` without these packages.

If they want to, they can download it with the `extra-packages.repos`.

In the future, we can think of similar non-essential external packages to this list.

Do you think this is reasonable? @esteve @mitsudome-r ?

@xmfcx I agree with you, the drivers are quite specific to the vehicle where Autoware is running, so it'd be better to move them to a separate `.repos` file and let users use whatever driver they need for their vehicle.

issues_title: Release Autoware packages into the ROS buildfarm
issues_comment_text:
Thanks for creating the issue.
Although this would help a lot of ROS users, I would like to think carefully about the timing and the target package.
 
I propose to do this after we do a clean up of messages (replacing autoware_auto_msgs with autoware_msgs). This is because change in interface could be quite a disruptive change and we would like to have more organized interface before making it ROS "official" release.

Also, I think we should only release into the ROS buildfarm for the packages in Core considering the fact that we defined Core as AWF maintained package and Universe to be community maintained. Universe packages can be registered to ROS buildfarm by the owner of the package at their decision. As Core is currently empty, we should start with porting Universe packages into Core first before doing this task.

issues_title: Release Autoware packages into the ROS buildfarm
issues_comment_text:
> Although this would help a lot of ROS users, I would like to think carefully about the timing and the target package.

Absolutely! This issue is just meant to start the discussion and find out what steps we'd need if we ever want to release Autoware into the ROS buildfarm, but I don't think we're ready now to do it.



> I propose to do this after we do a clean up of messages (replacing autoware_auto_msgs with autoware_msgs). This is because change in interface could be quite a disruptive change and we would like to have more organized interface before making it ROS "official" release.

Sounds good. I found https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware_msgs/issues/2 and I can work on it, if nobody else is working.

> Also, I think we should only release into the ROS buildfarm for the packages in Core considering the fact that we defined Core as AWF maintained package and Universe to be community maintained. Universe packages can be registered to ROS buildfarm by the owner of the package at their decision. As Core is currently empty, we should start with porting Universe packages into Core first before doing this task.

A priori I don't see the problem with releasing Autoware.Universe as well, but I understand that Autoware.Core is meant to be of higher quality, so it might make sense releasing it first.

However, the way package releases work with the ROS buildfarm is that [bloom](https://docs.ros.org/en/humble/How-To-Guides/Releasing/First-Time-Release.html#bloom-release) releases all the packages in a given repository (that's why it's required that all packages have the same version in their `package.xml`). So if we want to let community maintainers to release their packages on their own, they'll have to keep the packages in separate repositories and not all in Autoware.Universe. If anyone runs `bloom` on the Autoware.Universe repository, they'll release all the packages there.

issues_title: heaphook: roadmap to stable debian package
issues_comment_text:
With the release, I am closing the issue.

It is possible to perform `sudo apt install ros-humble-heaphook` right now.

https://github.com/ros/rosdistro/blob/master/humble/distribution.yaml#L2326-L2340

As all [PRs](https://github.com/orgs/autowarefoundation/discussions/3275#discussioncomment-5379038) intended for this phase of development regarding this feature have been merged, I am closing this issue as completed.
Thanks everyone who participated by any effort in this feature :+1:

@sykwer Thank you for adding this, but there are several things we need to clarify because editing `autoware.repos` means the dependency changes, which would cause a significant impact.

Usually, dependencies like this, which are third-party library-ish and won't change the interface frequently, should be released to APT as vendor packages.
See an example below:
https://github.com/tier4/hash_library_vendor
https://github.com/tier4/hash_library_vendor-release

If it's still in the development stage, I think it's okay to add it to `autoware.repos` for now.
However, the roadmap to the ideal state should be managed via an issue.
Therefore, please describe the roadmap around this dependency management.

Also, to merge this, you must get approvals from AWF's architects (@xmfcx @mitsudome-r). So I'll request a review from them. (I'll also request a review from one of TIER IV's architects @yukkysaito .)

@xmfcx @mitsudome-r 
I would appreciate your comments if you have any concerns 🙇

I'm sorry for waiting this long. I've checked it and it looks promising.

Until we make it more stable, let's keep it in .repos file and use it and experiment with it.

Thanks for working on this!

@sykwer What will be the first nodes to make use of this?

Will modifications to the nodes be necessary?

Or will just adding them into the launch configuration be enough?

I think the following 3 main packages could benefit a lot from this:
- https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe/tree/main/sensing/pointcloud_preprocessor
- https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe/tree/main/planning/behavior_velocity_planner
- https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware.universe/tree/main/planning/behavior_path_planner

issues_comment_text: I found another solution using array expansion: by making `targets` an array, the contents can properly be considered as multiple values through "${targets[@]}" instead of a single string. See f44fdeed

issues_title: fix(docker):  avoid empty string in bake's arguments when `targets` not specified
issues_comment_text:
> @kazuki0824 Thank you for your contribution! Could you describe what happens without this PR, and how did you fix it?  

@HansRobo 

Without this PR, docker/build.sh will fail.
If the option `--no-prebuilt` is not specified, then `$targets` will be set as follows: 
https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/blob/355538322f9fe8edd21cbbf37af623bb7a98ca8a/docker/build.sh#L38-L44
and then an empty string will be added to the bottom of the argv of the `bake` : 
https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/blob/355538322f9fe8edd21cbbf37af623bb7a98ca8a/docker/build.sh#L66-L76
@caiyuexiang Thank you! Could you please write some reasons for this change in the description section? It's for tracking in the future.

issues_title: Generate Debian packages for the ROS packages in Autoware.core and Autoware.universe
issues_comment_text:
I made some changes to actions to support a differential build. I would like to decide a release operation of Autoware and propose features to upstream to support it.

https://github.com/tier4/autoware-apt-testing/tree/main
https://github.com/isamu-takagi/ros-deb-builder-action/tree/develop (contains a lot of temporary code)

The features I think we need are:
- support differential build
- support multiple suite/components/architectures 
- use version in package.xml
- keep the old versions

So first, we need to decide how to release Autoware and how to manage the package version.

issues_title: Generate Debian packages for the ROS packages in Autoware.core and Autoware.universe
issues_comment_text: My idea is that each package will only build when the version tag in package.xml is changed, and the repository keeps all previously built versions.

issues_title: Generate Debian packages for the ROS packages in Autoware.core and Autoware.universe
issues_comment_text:
@isamu-takagi thanks for listing all the features, really nice.

I prefer to follow what MoveIt is doing:

https://github.com/moveit/moveit2_packages/blob/main/.github/workflows/build.yaml#L6

it runs once every day (in MoveIt's case, at 1:17am), so there's no need for differential builds, because it doesn't runs when a new branch is merged. But I think using the version from package.xml would be a useful alternative to using tags, though it's strongly encouraged for ROS packages/repositories to use tags for every new release.

Generate Debian packages for the ROS packages in Autoware.core and Autoware.universe
issues_comment_text:
> My concern is that the build takes a long time. If the dependent packages have not changed, it is efficient to use the released ones.

I measured about a minute for a package that is already in ccache on the free Github VMs. We can speed it up by using a ram disk if we have more powerful VMs. Also we think about parallelizing the build.
Note that it is not enough to compare the diff in the repo itself as upstream dependencies could have changed and require a rebuild (ABI changes, message changes..).

> > But I think using the version from package.xml would be a useful alternative to using tags, though it's strongly encouraged for ROS packages/repositories to use tags for every new release.
> 
> I think there is a request to use the old package version. in this case, If the package has not changed, the same binary will be generated as a different version.

Currently the package includes the date as a Debian revision to make sure new version are recognized as an update by apt. This is the same for the OSRF buildfarm. Generating a Debian revision only in case of a change is not trivial but we can discuss that.

Can you please send relevant patches upstream so we can discuss them?

@isamu-takagi I think flexible ways are better ways. I mean, reading the version in `package.xml` is suitable at least for Autoware as of today. If someone want to use Git tags, then they can update the version in `package.xml` when they create a tag.

issues_title: Generate Debian packages for the ROS packages in Autoware.core and Autoware.universe
issues_comment_text:
> @isamu-takagi I think flexible ways are better ways. I mean, reading the version in `package.xml` is suitable at least for Autoware as of today. If someone want to use Git tags, then they can update the version in `package.xml` when they create a tag.

Note that the `package.xml` version does not accommodate changes in git so new commits will have the same version number. That's why we use `git describe --tags`.

issues_title: Generate Debian packages for the ROS packages in Autoware.core and Autoware.universe
issues_comment_text:
> Note that the package.xml version does not accommodate changes in git so new commits will have the same version number. That's why we use git describe --tags.

What is the difference between tag and package.xml? New commits will have the same version unless a new tag is created. I think it can be replaced by just updating the package.xml instead of creating the tag. Did I miss something?

issues_title: Generate Debian packages for the ROS packages in Autoware.core and Autoware.universe
issues_comment_text:
> > Note that the package.xml version does not accommodate changes in git so new commits will have the same version number. That's why we use git describe --tags.
> 
> What is the difference between tag and package.xml? New commits will have the same version unless a new tag is created. I think it can be replaced by just updating the package.xml instead of creating the tag. Did I miss something?

Using `git describe --tags` will generate a version number specific to the used commit. It has the form `<tag>-<number of commits on top>-g<sha1 of commit>`. This makes sure that new commits have a higher version number (due to the counter) and that one can identify the commit belonging to the package (by the sha1).

issues_title: Generate Debian packages for the ROS packages in Autoware.core and Autoware.universe
issues_comment_text: Note that this is mostly relevant when creating packages for non tagged versions such as nightly builds. For tagged release builds `git describe --tags` will resolve to the tag so it should be the same as what is in the package.xml

issues_title: Generate Debian packages for the ROS packages in Autoware.core and Autoware.universe
issues_comment_text:
In conclusion, I found that there is no problem with version management by tags for a while.

After thinking about it, using tags is fine with for latest releases and nightly builds. For these, simply build the latest main branch or a specific tag. It's a bit unnatural for the version to be updated even if the package hasn't changed, but it doesn't matter.

My concern is for stable release. The reason I want to avoid using tags is that the Autoware repository is too large. Since the version of the repository is reflected in all packages, it is not possible to control the release timing for each package. This will the package is released with the latest code even if the package is not stable and maintainer want to provide the previous version as stable.

However, there is no problem with tag version at this stage. This is because the current Autoware is under development and it is difficult to provide a stable version. So as a first step, creating a tag for the entire autoware.universe and providing all packages with the same version of that tag is a reasonable choice.

In the future we need to support individual releases of packages. At this time, the version in package.xml is required, or split the repository. As @yukkysaito said, splitting the repository has the disadvantage of managing PR, but I hope that the code will be stable and easy to handle at this time.

issues_title: Generate Debian packages for the ROS packages in Autoware.core and Autoware.universe
issues_comment_text:
@jspricke @isamu-takagi Thank you for the additional information and summaries.

There was one thing I misunderstood.
When we say "use tags", I think there are two meanings:
1. Update packages only when a new tag is released.
2. Use tag-based information (such as `git describe --tags`) to determine the package versions, but they are built regularly.

I imagined the No. 1, but it seems the important point is mainly the No. 2, right?
In that case, I think it'd be okay for now.

In the future, perhaps we can consider other options like "updating packages only when package.xml is updated, and keeping all the versions (not only the latest) of deb packages.", as I mentioned above.
But I know there might be a problem then; the repository size would be extremely large.

Please correct me if I'm saying something wrong.

issues_title: Generate Debian packages for the ROS packages in Autoware.core and Autoware.universe
issues_comment_text:
Regarding stable releases, I think we can resolve it by preparing multiple repositories (channels).
For example, prepare the following 3 channels/repositories:
1. Stable/autoware-deb-packages-stable
2. Beta (Latest release)/autoware-deb-packages-beta
3. Nightly/autoware-deb-packages-nightly

It's very similar to Rust's way.
https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/appendix-07-nightly-rust.html

And set the different timings of updating the packages.
- Stable is updated when a maintainer manually updated the tag to use. It's assumed to be done after passing some tests such as scenario tests.
- Beta is updated when a new tag is pushed.
- Nightly is updated daily.

Then, users select the repository to use by changing the URL of add-apt-repository. (Or we can provide some commands to switch the channels.)

What do you think about it?

Hello, I was facing this same issue with both a single laptop and a dual-monitor setup. It happens to me when the screen resolution of either is set to 3840x2160 (4K). 

A solution to this is: 
1. Set your display to 1920x1080 or 100% scaling.
2. Start rviz2 with `rviz2 -d ~/autoware/install/autoware_launch/share/autoware_launch/rviz/autoware.rviz`
3. Uncheck the PointCloadMap visualization (Map > PointCloudMap). 
![image](https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/assets/35192516/b43bf34e-d2ff-4273-a881-961be37ae7e5)
6. Save the autoware.rviz config.
7. Set the display back to your native resolution and desired scaling.
8. Start rviz2 again with `rviz2 -d ~/autoware/install/autoware_launch/share/autoware_launch/rviz/autoware.rviz`

This way the PointCloudMap topic is not visualized on startup since PointCloudMap consumes a lot of memory. I was able to enable the PointCloudMap again after startup. It seems that rviz2 consumes a lot of memory on launch when rendering on a 4K screen and unchecking PointCloudMap helps reduce the load. Hope this helps.
